So, if your grinder doesn't seem to be working like it should, contact customer service!

I posted a two start review a while ago and the company reached out to me and sent me a replacement grinder for free. They were very nice and the grinder was shipped to me very quickly, however I was out of whole bean coffee so I've only just now gotten around to trying it out.

The new grinder was much smoother and I was able to feel when to stop since the resistance decreases significantly. It was much smoother an easier than with the original grinder I got and I was able to grind 25 grams of coffee (my usual amount for my 16oz pour over) in about 90 seconds. I'm updating my review to four starts for the excellent service and the fact that the grinder does work pretty darn well. Thanks to the JavaPresse folks and their excellent support!

Old Review:
Good for the Aeropress and nothing else

If you want a coffee grinder that's small and portable to use with an Aeropress somewhere where you can't make too much noise, this will work great for you. Unfortunately, it doesn't really work for anything else. Even on the coarsest setting the grounds I get from this are too fine for my pour over and I can't even imagine how tedious it would be to use this for finer grinds like espresso.

What I like about the JavaPresse, it looks sleek, simplistic and isn't intimidating to use. It grinded well, and made great coffee. Clean up was a relative breeze. I can see using this on a daily basis... with a few caveats....

1) the compartment on the bottom (which catches the ground coffee) needs to be either tighter or lockable via a twist. The first day I used it, I gripped onto the main body of the grinder and started my process and halfway through the bottom fell out.... all my hard work grinding thus far was on the floor... what a mess...

2) the necessity to hold the bottom compartment makes it difficult to hold the main body firmly while grinding. This was especially true for finer grinds (I was using it for my Aeropress) and noticed that if I didn't hold the body firmly it would just start spinning, but trying to hold both compartments (body and bottom grind compartment) was a strain on my hand and arm. If there was a silicone grip on the body, it would make it much easier (that or textured metal) because the shiny smooth steel makes it hard to prevent it from spinning alongside the grinder arm.

Other than that, I have been enjoying this fun little grinder and making consistent grinds for my daily coffee.

Recommended!

reviews.reviewTitle: Simply Designed and Constructed, Missing Protective Bag
reviews.reviewText:
[updated 2/10/19] I tested this on some whole roasted beans from Peets. It was almost an enjoyable experience for me, just standing in the kitchen rotating the crank. Granted I wasnt in a rush, but I could turn out enough grounds for a 13oz French Press fairly quickly. Its a manual grinder, dont expect quick grounds.

- - - - - -

Im going to fully review after Ive tried the grinder in conjunction with their free month of coffee offer. But...

...after unboxing, I realized they havent really addressed how to protect it on the go, given that its main convenience is its portability (in my opinion). Am I just supposed to throw this in a backpack or briefcase as two pieces? I personally wont lose the handle, but Im sure others will if theyre packed separately. Furthermore, the beautiful stainless steel will become nicked and scratched over time if left to GRIND around with keys, pens, loose change, etc. I almost expected it to come in a drawstring bag...

If JavaPresse ends up reading this, you should design and distribute a cylindrical drawstring bag with an externally-attached sleeve for the handle. Imagine how suave this product would look coming out of a microfiber black bag - from a modern apartment to camping in the wilderness!

If anyone has the skill to make one for me, Ill take it as a donation for the idea - ha!

The grinder arrived on time and as described. I have used it only once, but so far, so good. It ground beans on course setting for French Press and they came out very good. I have not tried any other grind settings. The instructions give the recommended settings for multiple grind options. The setting knob for finest/courseness does not appear to have as many clicks to left/right as suggested { course setting 13-18 clicks ), more like 10-11 max. This does not hinder the performance on the grinder, however. The handle just slips over the shaft on top, no screw down, This easy takedown is nice for storage as the crank arm is not sticking out. You will be cranking for awhile, but the results speak for themselves and I recommend it. 4 stars, because time has not been a measurable factor yet and there is always something better to be discovered. Enjoy.

While it does take a little more time and effort to use, the results are worth it. The grounds are consistent on a medium grind at 8-9 clicks, the more coarse the less consistent but that stands to reason. For 1/3 cup of medium grounds, fill the bean reservoir and grind away. It takes about 4 minutes to grind. The crank handle seats well and turning is not difficult. We bought this to go with the
Bodum Pour Over Coffee Maker https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00LOCYKIQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
using low-acid Tres Hermanos organic coffee https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B074FNDMJD/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1. You will not be disappointed.

Two issues...
1) Uneven grind - I am getting an entire spectrum of grind sizes. Without any beans in it, brand new, I could hear the burr scraping one side. I can push it away from the side and it will stop but it should not have that much movement in the first place.
2) Loose base - The base and main body are not very tight. I thought they would screw together but it just pulls apart. The connection is not that tight. Am I really expected to hold both parts at the same time with one hand while grinding with the other?

reviews.reviewTitle: Better than my Cuisinart by far
reviews.reviewText: I bought a Cuisinart coffee grinder from Target a few months ago. I'll admit I'm a coffee noob so I had no idea that my purchase was going to be a bad one. I figured Cuisinart makes some quality kitchen gadgets so they couldn't fail at something as simple as a coffee grinder right? Wrong! As this is not a review of the Cuisinart, I will tell you that his little hand grinder, although VERY slow, blew the more expensive electric contraption out of the water! The grind was more consistent and had no powder residue like its electric counterpart. My cups of Joe taste more consistent every morning and without all the funky sediment that the other machine left behind. The ONLY drawback thus far after a week of use is, I have to make coffee for both my wife and me and we drink A LOT! 5 cups between the both of us. Using a coffee formula on the internet, I found that I have to grind two and a half mills (around 66 grams) of coffee for our French press every single morning. This act roughly equates to an extra 20 mins just in coffee prep for me. Is it worth it? Hell yeah, it is! Now my little almost brand new Cuisinart sits on the counter unused, so if anyone wants to buy a cheap coffee grinder, hit me up! Seriously, buy this thing, it will change the way you make coffee.

I've decided to give it 5 stars, I debated giving 4.

I do pour overs daily in a Bodum carafe. Double filtered because I want paper filters, but have to use a basket regardless. This slows the drip rate, so I must grind more coarse.

My grinder is set to a 14-15 click setting and it takes me 1.5 minutes to ground 20g of coffee. Double the amount, double the time basically. The hopper seems to only fit 40g of my coffee, but I drink 50g everyday.. so I have to do two groups of grinding. Not really an issue. It takes about as long to grind as it takes my kettle to heat up, so I don't see much of a difference in brew time. Just effort.

Overall, a decent grinder. Kind of slow, but what do you expect from a hand grinder? I'm sure with finer grinds it will be longer, so be aware.

I bought this grinder a few weeks ago, and I usually only need to dial in a grinder once or twice to find a grind setting I like, but with this one, I've had to adjust it every single time I use it. I have not been able to find a setting I like. It's either been too fine or too coarse. It's also incredibly inconsistent; I typically grind 20g of beans at a time, it will start out grinding normally but then as it gets to the end of the coffee it gets immensely more coarse. It also always gets giant chunks of coarse grounds stuck in it no matter how fine the grind starts. I'm very unsatisfied with this product. I will be searching for a better alternative that can do its job.

reviews.reviewTitle: Handle Rusted & water retained in between the plastic and metal!
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this product based on the good reviews, but ended up being so disappointed!!!

First, the plastic part inside the mill is not well sealed, so you can see in my first picture that there is water remained in between the plastic and the metal, after each rinse!

Second, the handle got rusted after ONE rinse before I used it (not even with any detergent, I just rinse it with water and let it air dry over night).

Thirdly, the grinding is not as smooth as it seems to be.

I use this every other day to prepare coarse grounds for cold brew. Its not fast, but for personal use its fine. My only complaint then was that there was no detent or clicks I read about them having to have a consistent grind setting. I assume my model was an older version. My first one lasted about 3 months before the black plastic piece that holds the ceramic burr on the shaft broke in half. That was a bummer but customer service did me a solid. They sent me an upgraded replacement burr to fix it (New white plastic piece vs old black piece) and a second, upgraded model.

I now exclusively use the new unit as it is superior, has detents for consistent sized grinds, and the nut (what determines the size) doesnt seem to want to fall off like the last one.

Do not get this unit if you have an issue with grinding out grounds for minutes and have multiple people waiting on the results. I only use it for about 100 grams every two days for my own needs and its perfect, and somewhat therapeutic.

The customer service rep was great to work with and gave me more than I expected.

As others have mentioned, the customer service at JavaPresse is excellent. The first grinder I purchased was defective and Jacque immediately sent out another one. The second one works okay but it's still not very clear which setting the grinder is on. The grinder settings are based on the number of clicks but the clicks are inconsistent or too subtle to hear. So I was essentially flying blind when it came to the grind setting.

The second issue is how long it takes to grind one scoop of beans. I'd say it took me about 3-4 minutes to fully grind all the beans. I love the concept of not burning the beans with an electric motor but hand grinding them is a big effort. Too much effort at 6:30 am. Probably too much at noon. Having said that, I would recommend this grinder for travel, for camping, etc., but not as your main grinder. Unless you have wildly muscular wrists or you're thinking about living off the grid.

SLOW but terrific. But what can you expect from a single burr manual crank grinder. It is going to be slow. I use the finest grind in my moka pots. It is faster on a coarse grind like for French press. My grinder has NOT broken despite daily use for months. I even hooked mine up to a cordless drill once or twice like another reviewer suggested, which I'm sure the manufacturer does not advise. It worked, but it was still a bit slow, granted I didn't use max speed on the drill. Anyway, if you don't mind cranking away for a few minutes each morning (or better, each night to prepare for the next day), definitely buy this. Also would make a great camping tool for long trips (I would just bring fresh grounds on a short trip). I will eventually pony up for an electric conical ceramic burr grinder.

Super surprised with the performance of this grinder. I was originally shopping for an electric burr grinder, but after seeing a polar price range and the very mixed reviews, I decided to give a manual burr grinder a try. I've had mine for about a month and it's been used a few times now. It keeps an even grind and makes for wonderful coffee in my french press. It does have some pieces when it's disassembled to clean that you have to keep an eye on because they are small (a couple washers and the spring inside), but I have to disassemble my french press anyways, so I don't mind.

I ran into a small issue after reassembling the first time. I discovered that the black, star shaped piece that twists to set the grind size has grooves on one side, but not the other. When reassembling, you need to be sure to have the grooves facing the white grinder, or else it won't make the "clicks" to recalibrate the grinder. Also, if facing the wrong way, the black piece and grinder will adjust as you turn the handle, making an uneven grind size.

Customer service is super nice, quick to respond, and helpful!

After figuring that out, I'm quite happy with the purchase!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Portable Coffee Grinder - Most Bang for Your Buck
reviews.reviewText: This is a great grinder for coffee lovers. I have been testing several different grind levels for my french press and have found that this grinder produces a high quality coarse grind. I wish it had an indicator on the side that told you which level of coarseness you were set on but it is easy to reset and count the clicks. I'd recommend it if you don't want to spend the money on an electric grinder.

I bought this grinder in the event of power outages, and secondarily for camping. It seems sturdy enough, and ground up a test batch of beans very nicely. The coarseness is easily adjustable, and can grind down to Turkish coffee fineness. As the seller's images show, it is slim, about the diameter of a paper towel core, so is easy for a small adult hand to grip. The handle slips on and off easily - it's not fastened - so it can be stored compactly.

My only quibble is with the free coffee offer. Sure, it's not unreasonable for them to ask me to pay shipping, but I wanted to know how much that would be before committing to pay it. I didn't give them my card number, and aborted the process. I'd knock off a star for this, except the product is very nice.

Was not sure what to expect, so took a chance and bought. My electric blade grinder broke, my electric mill or burr grinder is at work. Very difficult to locate an inexpensive burr grinder locally so took to amazon because that is what we do now. The manual idea was intriguing, picture looked nice. Received, packaged excellent with plenty bubble wrap. No Scratch's on brushed steel. There are no threads for the top and bottom, it is a snug compression fit, slightly difficult to pull apart initially, once done no need to press together with much force. Tried the fine grind first as that was how it shipped. This took awhile and I was not sure it was working, so watch their video or loosen to half way between fine and course and you will be pleased. We are talking single cup brewing. No mess as with electric grinders, my number 1 reason,
2 pours beautifully into single cup filter 3 no cord 4 sleek enough to leave out and I place near my salt and pepper grinders. Highly recommended and makes for a great cup of Joe. Well done JavaPresse!

I was convinced by the stellar reviews that this would be a decent grinder for the price, boy was I wrong. The first one I got was off center and the ceramic burr would grind on itself, so it was useless. They sent a prompt replacement that ended up being even more off than the first one. Steer clear of this super cheap and flimsy grinder. Even with the burr problem, the metal feels paper thin and there are a lot of plastic components that can and probably will eventually break. Very poor quality.

My husband and I love coffee, espresso and cappuccino! Over the years, Ive made coffee in our Mr. Coffee and Cuisinart Grind & Brew, as well as Keurig coffee makers. Once we received the JavaPresse, I pulled out our French Press that we havent used in a long time and made delicious coffee! The JavaPresse perfectly grinds coffee beans to brew in any type of coffee maker. All you have to do is grind about six beans to find the right consistency for your personal taste and the type of coffee youre brewing...I have found that a coarser grind is perfect for a French Press, a medium fine grind works well in a Keurig, and a fine grind is best for espresso. Im looking forward to making cold brew coffee in the summer with coarse grounds. I am very impressed with the JavaPresse company and their customer service. The grinder was packaged nicely and included instructions and suggestions for its use. They have also emailed me about three times to thank me for the order as well as checking on my satisfaction. If you love coffee and appreciate the difference in its taste from grinding fresh coffee beans, please do not hesitate to order the JavaPresse grinder!

reviews.reviewTitle: A great product for a couple people
reviews.reviewText:
I really enjoy good coffee and preparing it well, but my spouse is not a coffee drinker. This was a perfect size for me and, if needed, one other person to have a great cup of coffee together. I would not recommend this grinder if you are trying to grind for more than two people, but it is a perfect for one or two people.

The manual grinding takes some time, but that's what you'd expect with a manual grinder. It is really quick if you use a french press, but it'll take more time the finer you want a grind. With my French press, I can get the water heating and easily grind all the coffee I need before my water is hot enough. The grind is good and easily adjusted, though I wish that the click instructions were etched into the side of the grinder for easy access. I really like the removable handle as it makes the grinder convenient for travel or in a small kitchen without the space for something larger.

The only two things I wish were that it was easier to clean (not terribly difficult, but its size makes it challenging) and that it had a larger opening for the whole beans. It's convenient size means that a person has to be careful when loading the grinder.

Overall, happy with this product.

Bought this for home use .. ( my first mistake) grinding a few cups worth of coffee is a massive chore with this grinder. It takes about 10 minutes to grind 4 or five ccuos worth of Java. The handle just rests on the top on a hex bolt and is not secured it easily comes off in your hand while spinning.
The outer stainless body conceals a plastic liner (bean hopper) that stays in place via a tiny notch and corresponding indent in the stainless outer body. This keeps it from spinning with the handle .. or does it?
The alleged ceramic grinding wheel is tiny hence the minuscule amount of beans going through it per minute. I cant see this mechanism lasting more than a month of daily use. This is a great travel companion on a camping trip but avoid if you are a daily home coffee lover.

reviews.reviewTitle: A nice addition to my kitchen
reviews.reviewText:
This is my first manual coffee grinder, so I can offer no comparisons to other manual grinders. I've had it for about a week, and I'm still learning how to 'tune' it, grind-wise. My only negative, and it's not the fault of the grinder, is that you're going to need to do a bit of work for your coffee. I've rediscovered arm muscles that have been unused for too long. But I'm adjusting quickly.

The grinder itself is easy to hold and has a clean look to it. I'm still adjusting my grind. I use a fairly new Moccamaster cone filter drip coffee maker with an electric grinder (Black & Decker) which has flat grinding mill wheels for a long time. Coffee from the JavaPresse grinder smells better, richer than grounds from the electric. There's also another layer of taste that I didn't get before, but that seems to vary quickly with grind settings, so I'm still 'tweaking' the grind.

All in all, an excellent addition to my kitchen, and the little bit of work it takes to get your morning cuppa makes the taste more savory. And it's a WHOLE lot quieter than the electric was.

This product is supremely high quality, durable and versatile! Ive been using it everyday! I have a keurig, nespresso, French press, and an espresso machine. Im finding myself manually grinding my coffee every morning just so that I can make an aeropress cup of coffee! The flavor is so balanced, silky, and smooth! And even after the coffee gets cold, it still tastes good! If you prefer drinking lots of coffee, I would recommend an auto grinder for your fresh beans so that you can make multiple cups at a time. Im really satisfied with this affordable product and Im quite picky about my coffee. I purchase a lot from Amazon and rarely leave reviews, however, this product has truly impressed me and I like the email that was sent to me asking me how I liked my aeropress coffee maker. As a small family entrepreneur myself, I can definitely relate! Hopefully one day perhaps aeropress will let me help them sell their product internationally abroad, like Asia!

I plan to take aeropress along with me to all of my travels! Its so convenient to do so in their complementary travel bag! No more bad coffee at hotels!

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds uniformly for French press coffee maker!
reviews.reviewText: I purchased a French press coffee maker and was researching how to make the perfect brew. I came across an article on thekitchn.com who pointed out that a blade grinder (which is what I had) would not grind uniformly and a French press requires a uniform, coarse grind. They recommended this particular grinder and I am very pleased! I looked up their instructional video and in 5 minutes I knew what to do. I love that it holds exactly the amount of beans that I need for 2 cups of coffee, which is what I typically brew for myself, so no measuring needed! I also love that I this grinder has settings for the degree of coarseness so I just adjust the setting and grind until all the beans have been ground. No guesswork! JavaPresse even included a coupon for a free bag of their coffee, which I look forward to trying out. They also sent a follow-up email to see if I was happy with my purchase. Great product and customer support!

reviews.reviewTitle: Doesn't stay together and gets metal dust in your coffee
reviews.reviewText:
Grinds coffee well and looks nice, but doesn't have clicks/settings like I thought it would and it took a few tries to get it right. I also noticed that the top edge of the lid rubs against the handle as it it turning and creates a very fine metal dust that makes its way into the chamber, and thus, the coffee.

But my biggest complaint is that the three stainless pieces (the main grinding portion, the bottom reservoir, and the lid) don't stay together at all, so you have to hold the lid without the handle swinging and knocking your fingers while you grind, while pressing against a table or other surface. If you want to walk around and grind with this, you need to be able to hold both the lid and the bottom piece to the main grinding body, which requires large, strong hands. I have big hands, but my hands usually get cramped from holding this together every day and I usually also have to hold it against my stomach or leg as well. After 4 months with this, I can't deal with it anymore, so I'm getting a new one. I'm surprised I haven't seen more people mention this issue.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice for the price. Much better than a blade grinder.
reviews.reviewText:
This is not a $200-$400 coffee grinder. It's not reasonable to expect a perfectly uniform grind from a grinder under $30. It's still much better than a blade grinder as it doesn't turn a quarter of your coffee beans into dust.

This unit feels sturdy and grinds quietly. My old blade grinder was louder than a commercial vacuum cleaner. The trick to getting a decent grind out of this device is to run your grounds through TWICE. I thought I wasn't setting it fine enough at first as there were large chunks of bean in my grounds after one pass. After two passes, you get a pretty consistent grind.

It doesn't take very long to grind enough beans (just under four tablespoons) for my small french press. Maybe a little bit longer than it takes my electric kettle to heat up the water, which happens rather quickly. I haven't timed it but it's not a bothersome amount of time.

If you're looking to grind coffee for large batches, say for drip coffee, you'll have to do several batches to get enough grounds. You're probably still going to want an electric burr grinder for that. Unless you just need the workout.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good for Those Who May Move Abroad
reviews.reviewText:
In buying a coffee grinder, I opted to go non-electric, as I may eventually move to another country where the voltage differs and US electrical appliances won't work. Having done this before, I had to leave many items behind that I am now having to replace, having returned to the States. This grinder, so far, works well, though I am still having to figure out the right coarseness for my French press. The one downside is that it takes longer than the reviews stated to grind 4 Tablespoons of grounds needed for my morning pot. Rather than the 2 minutes quoted, I found that it takes twice as long. Since I am not much of a morning person until I've had some coffee, I have found it works best to grind the next mornings batch the night before. Not the optimal arrangement, as the sooner the coffee is ground, it seems the fresher the coffee, but it is working for me.

This grinder has a 2 year warranty, but then the directions state the burr grinding mechanism may be worn down and require replacement. I have no idea how much that may cost. My last electric grinder was going on 8 years old when I had to leave it behind in the States. I am a bit disappointed to anticipate having to do this within a few years, and I hope that the price is reasonable to replace the burrs.

The grinder is very compact and attractively designed. I have some arthritis in my hands, but using this grinder has not put any undue stress or caused pain in my hands. The grinder is easy to use; it just takes longer than I anticipated. Overall, so far, I am satisfied with my purchase. We'll see how I feel in 2 years, should I have to replace the burrs and find out their cost!

Have wanted a burr coffee grinder, but have not wanted to pay the expensive price. Have a Chemex coffee maker as well as a French press coffee maker and have wanted fresh ground coffee for them. I love the ritual of making an aromatic and delicious cup of coffee.came across the JavaPresse coffee grinder while researching pour over coffee products, read many of the reviews and decided to order one. Its easy to use and Im going to strengthen my grip from holding the grinder while turning the handle. Im still experimenting with the precise grind for me, but it works well, grinds smoothly and the videos online are helpful for cleaning the JavaPresse. So far so good. Im happy with my little JavaPresse and would recommend it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect tool for a perfect cup, just takes some time
reviews.reviewText:
This is the only hand grinder for coffee that I have ever used so take what I have to say with a grain of salt.

It does a perfect job of grounding up coffee and maybe it is just me but the coffee I make now just taste better. It comes with basic instructions and a site to check out some videos for use/cleaning. So easy to use somewhat easy to clean. The one drawback is that it does take a long time to actually grind the coffee. My morning routine allows me to spend 5-7 minutes grinding my morning coffee but can see how that could be problematic for some. To grind for a group of three or more would be a time consuming process unless everyone really enjoyed grinding coffee. That said I didnt want to take any stars off because given 30 seconds of thought it should be obvious to this would be the case (obviously I did not have this thought). Anyway its a great little coffee grinder I currently find myself using. Also I got a free bag of coffee which I have yet to try

I know this is an amazons choice best seller, but dont believe the hype! This product is not a quality product. From the uneven grind, to the burrs not grabbing the effectively, to the flimsiness of the material (specifically the bottom chamber) I would not recommend this grinder even though it has a low price tag. Tried this against the Porlex and there is no comparison. The Porlex is 3 times as expensive, but 5 times the quality of the Javapresse. Not to mention the daily ponzee scheme-like/self-help emails I got from Raj trying to seem like hes my buddy or mentor. Or that this actually seems to be a generic product design used by other unknown companies as well (javapresse just slaps there logo on it??). Do yourself a favor if your serious about investing in a quality product and skip on the Javapresse manual coffee grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great portability, easy to use, has expected considerations.
reviews.reviewText: Takes longer for very fine grind and can be fatiguing but this should be expected if you desire a very fine grind in a manual grinder. The small diameter is easy to hold in the hand but can be difficult after grinding for a while. There is no securing the grinder handle to the top so it is possible that the handle can come off while grinding but this is rarely an issue. The grind at finer levels through most all of the coarsest appear to be very consistent. I have made drip, pour over, espresso and Turkish and all came out well with some experimentation to find the best grind. Overall construction is solid and no instability is felt while grinding. The clear window in the grinder cup allows for viewing of the amount of coffee ground. The knob on the bottom of the grinder burr allows for selecting your grind size by "clicks". This feels a bit sloppy and loose but the "clicks" are easily felt when turning the knob. Overall, nice grinder, easily portable if you love your beans to go.

reviews.reviewTitle: I was so disappointed. When I took it out of the package
reviews.reviewText: I was so disappointed. When I took it out of the package, I couldn't pull the pieces apart and had to recruit my husband. It must have been air tight or something because when he finally got it, it seemed fine and came apart easier. The second time I used it however, the black knob fell off because the bolt is not long enough to resist the amount of turning of the handle that is required. I tried using two screwdrivers (yeah awkward) to reattach it but it just keeps popping off no matter how tight I get it. I thought maybe the bolt broke but there isn't a piece inside and I can't find a piece so I'm guessing it was supposed to be that short? Not sure. I will be returning it.

I make incense, and I bought this to grind the things that take too much time and effort to grind with a mortar and pestle. IT'S AMAZING. Turns easily, adjusts easily, cleans easily, and gives me a really consistent grind all the way down to the finest powder. We don't use bladed electric grinders because they heat the ingredients enough that they release too much of their fragrance constituents. This kind of assisted hand grinding produces the best result for things that depend on keeping all their lovely aromas intact. I imagine this is just as important in a cup of coffee as it is in a jar of incense. I'm buying a second one for coffee. Should be a real flavor revelation!

I use this with a v60 at the cabin, camp ground, airbnb, and hotel when we don't want to bring along our larger grinder. I even use when we're at home occasionally. It's very compact without sacrificing a decent grind. My only complaint is that the grind adjustment would be difficult to dial in if you need to change it often. It's not a big deal if you're using the same brewing method most of the time. I give it a few clicks in either direction depending on the roast, but if you don't use it for a while it's hard to remember where your baseline is at.

reviews.reviewTitle: Steep learning curve, frustrating to use
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this product looking for a gateway into home brewed coffee at an affordable price, willing to trade a few minutes each morning for affordability to do so. Unfortunately my experience so far has been frustrating and the coffee I've brewed disappointing.

The instructions are unclear and unhelpful. I've spent a few hours over the past week alone trying to figure out how to configure the grind quality between rereading the instructions multiple times, rewatching the video they link you, and just testing it out by hand, and I still cannot figure out how to properly do this. You're told you do this by "turning it all the way to the right and hearing x amount of clicks", but after turning knobs for too long in either direction, I'm not given any obvious cues to tell me how to adjust it properly. First I grinded them too coarsely, then I somehow was able to adjust it to its finest setting and I can't get out out of it. Being able to adjust this should be obvious!

This is on top of the time commitment actually grinding the coffee, which as users have pointed out can take at least 2 minutes but for me has taken closer to 5. It doesn't seem like much, but 2-5 minutes of actively grinding beans is deceptively long and it adds up. Imagine you're planking 2-5 minutes and that's how pleasant the experience is.

It pains me to leave this review because this is a small business that seems to genuinely care about its product and customers. I really wanted to start enjoying the home brewing experience, but unfortunately I can't recommend this product to anyone given the frustrating experience I've had with it.

Okay, so I've never had a manual grinder before, but just using this one for the past few weeks, I love it. It is definitely good quality and I'm anticipating it lasting me a long time. I will say that the "clicking" mechanism took me a couple minutes to figure out, but honestly if you get confused you can SEE the amount of space between the burr and the mill (small space=smaller grounds, yeah?) It's stylish looking and great for my home use purposes. It holds a decent amount of coffee and I'm not going to lie, if I grind a little too much, I leave it in the catcher part of the grinder until next time I need some espresso. It hasn't affected the taste at all.

reviews.reviewTitle: Compact design has trade-offs - mediocre stability, speed, and ease of use
reviews.reviewText:
For price and functionality, this is a good product - but if you don't need the "portability" of a slender grinder, with a removable handle, you may be happier with another product that has more heft and stability.

Tall, narrow design is difficult to hold stable as one grinds coffee. It wiggles around in your hands. The top and bottom parts will start to move independently unless one grips them properly. You can't rest the base on a counter for additional stability because of the narrow design.

Takes me about 4 mins to grind 25 grams of java beans. I have to switch hands along the way.

It does the job and the price is right. Though, I wish I had gotten a product that I could rest on a counter as I ground the beans.

reviews.reviewTitle: Will not lie - I'm not a fan
reviews.reviewText: I can not say anything special about quality. It's not stellar. It's just fine. As for durability - only after using it for a long time I can either recommend or not. But I was totally disappointed overall by the idea of using a manual grinder. When I make cappuccino I used to go with double-shots. With an electric grinder, it took about 3-4 min to have a cup ready. Multiply by a number of people. The manual grinder adds about 4-5 min per serving. It's funny but it takes me less time to pump up an inflatable paddle board! I get it - sometimes it may work as a meditation. But the most of the times it's less than convenient.

I have been getting about the same variability in grind as with a simple electric blade grinder, which makes the product worthless to me. There is play in the burr assembly that allows it to become offset as soon as you begin grinding. After looking at the assembly, it's clear to me that there's no way to prevent this (the shaft is metal and the support is plastic). I'm having a hard time figuring out how so many people gave this product a good review, though plenty of people who gave three or four stars still complain of an uneven grind. I'm not going to add a couple stars to my review because the brushed steel looks pretty in my kitchen. Junk is junk.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use and a great grind
reviews.reviewText: This is a great grinder for your small batch coffee or for taking with you on the road. To set the grind, you have to start at "0" then work back to get it to the grind texture you want. I just set it in the middle, ground a little bit and checked then adjusted from there. Pretty simple. I would definitely recommend this. It's about the size of a home version of a pepper mill. Handle comes off at the top and is easily broken down for storage.

reviews.reviewTitle: Price, Performance, Service: A Great Burr Grinder.
reviews.reviewText:
Verified Purchase. I purchased the Java Press Maual Burr Grinder 6/16. I wanted to replace my Krups electric blade gender and get a coarse grind for a French Press and Percolator. I use several brands of Organic beans, from Costco, on-line sites and local roasters
The Java Press produces a nice coarse grind for my tastes and is simple to operate and easy to clean. I clean every 2-3 weeks and recommend using a bowl of warm soapy water to soak the parts, then rinse and dry on a paper towel. Make certain you have both the black plastic and metal washers to bookend the spring and be careful around the sink.

I have taken the grinder and my French Press trailer camping along with a good supply of bean. Grind, brew
and drink, no problem. Also I take the the Java Press in my carry-on when flying - Not necessary to forego a great cup of coffee when you travel.

Bedst part: The company website is extremely helpful and Irene and Raj are available for email questions They deeply care that we are satisfied customers and will go the distance to provide excellent servic. When the black plastic insert in the reovable burr got cracked, I eamiled Irene at Java Press, a photo of the issue. She was on it immediately and sent a replacement grinder with the newest burr that contains a nylon center suppot, an upgrade over plastic. Her support was off the chart.

The Java Press is a 5 star winner for a manual burr grinder and the customer service gets 10 Stars** Java Press is one of the best values at Amazon and will produce the grind you need to fine-tune a great cup of Joe. I grind every morning and in a few minutes have fresh gound beans
steeping away. Quality product + excellent support. Go with it.

reviews.reviewTitle: It does what it says it will do
reviews.reviewText:
This is my first coffee bean grinder ever and I am very pleased with it. I use it to make one or two cups of coffee each morning. It does take a moment to grind up all the beans, but this isn't really an issue. It would be if you were aiming to make larger pots each day. Overall it is exactly what I expected it to be.

UPDATE: This product randomly stopped working. One day I put the lid back on and when I went to rotate the handle to grind the beans, it just wasn't working. I didn't use this device more than 10 times so I don't understand what happened. Extremely disappointing because I was initially so happy with the product

!!! SECOND UPDATE: I contacted the company through their website and they sent me a new one free of charge. It works great and I am very happy with it so long as it keeps working! Will update if it breaks down but otherwise assume it's fine. Great customer service, thank you JavaPresse!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great buy overall, impressive little grinder!
reviews.reviewText:
I really love this coffee grinder. It feels solid, it's just the right size, and there's enough adjustment to get just the right grind. It looks amazing and I think it will last me a very long time. I'm glad I purchased this instead of a more expensive electric grinder; I was debating for quite some time prior to purchasing.

The only thing I dislike about this grinder is that it constantly wants to fall apart at the middle where the two halves come together. You have to be sure to hold them both together while cranking the handle on top while grinding or the bottom half drops off and you lose all your freshly ground coffee. Seems like it should have been machined a little closer in tolerance so they held together more securely? Unsure if this is with all of them or if mine is defective.

reviews.reviewTitle: Plastic washers break, this item is not suited for daily use
reviews.reviewText:
Works perfectly so far, just what I was looking for.

Revised 1/18/18 to say that unfortunately one of the plastic washers inside had broken and a lot of the ground coffee is ending up on the wrong side of the grinding mechanism, I'd have to clean it every day and that is not ideal.

Revised 5/19/19 The replacement the company sent after the first revision was welcome, and their customer service was good, but this product has one fatal flaw that renders it unsuitable for daily use: the plastic washers instead are not holding up, I've gone through four of them now, and I'd basically have to keep buying the replacement washers for $5 at least once a year. I'll look for another product that is more durable in the long run.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great compact manual grinder for coffee!
reviews.reviewText:
This product is perfect for grinding the beans for one pot of coffee (1.2 L french press). I can grind the beans before the water has boiled, with time to spare. It is not at all difficult to grind the beans, about the same effort required for beating eggs for an omelet. The unit is easy to assemble/disassemble to load, empty, and clean. It is compact for easy storage, and lightweight for easy transport, and easy to adjust for finer or coarser grind. It is also much less irritating than the whine of an electric machine, and, being manual, does not require electricity. It is sleek and attractive as well!
I cannot comment on durability since I have only had it for a few days; however, I have used it several times, with no problems.

The grinder works very well and is very simple. I do appreciate how easy it is to use and its great portability. The grinder does produce an even grind at various fineness (I tested a couple different ones). It is easy to clean and to reassemble. The handle is quite ergonomic and comfortable to grind.

The complaints that I have are that it's hard to determine what grind you specifically have with the knob. There is no simple guide included that tells you how many "clicks" to utilize for different brewing methods and I found it cumbersome to experiment until I figured it out.
I also think that the seller is underestimating the time required to grind the beans. It takes longer than I was anticipating.
Lastly, it only holds about 600g of coffee (about a heaping 1/4 cup). I suppose that if you're using more than that, you may use another method of grinding, but it would be nice to have that option if I were ambitious.

As someone else has already pointed out, it can take a little experimentation to get the grind set to the right point, but it's fun testing it out to get exactly what you want. I've found exactly what I want, but I've also found some interesting variations that give a noticeable change in the flavor. It's small enough to pack while traveling and well constructed. I've especially enjoyed having it with me to test out a new bean I come across before buying a larger quantity. It has earned a permanent place on the kitchen counter, except for when it's in my suitcase.

reviews.reviewTitle: Watch out for really sharp edges!
reviews.reviewText:
Not much else could be said about this grinder. It's good. Docked a star because the edges are very sharp. I chuckled at the directions that had a warning about the edges. Karma got me shortly thereafter. Out of the box I pre washed it and was drying it by awkwardly shoving a paper towel into the catch end of it. Ended up with a bunch of paper like cuts in between index and pointer. When I have time I will take some sandpaper and soften the edges... IMO the manufacturer should do this.

Other than that it grinds really well. I notice with large AA beans it isn't as efficient but still gets the job done. Normal size beans, even with a fine grind, just takes a couple minutes to grind for a single serve. Nice warm up in the morning to get the blood flowing. Grinding for two cups of coffee occasionally is fine. Mostly intended for a single cup. Wouldn't want to grind for more than 2+ cups though.

reviews.reviewTitle: Use a cordless drill for better results
reviews.reviewText: Wanted to have really good coffee, I was told you needed a ceramic Burr grinder and do it by hand. Well, I tried, gave me really fine grounds for my automatic drip, but it took me a half hour to get 2 tablespoons, seriously people, I'm not freaking Amish, I dont have the patience. So I took off the handle and attached my DeWalt cordless drill to the bit on top, it has variable speeds, so I could still go slow, just not hand grind slow. Now I make grinds in 5 minutes. Perfect....

reviews.reviewTitle: All your bean are belong to us
reviews.reviewText:
I have never had a bean grinder. I wanted to get some Death Wish Coffee to try and I figured if I got the whole beans and some re-usable Nespresso cups that I could make my own little espresso rockets to get me through the day.
Pros, it works and it appears to work just fine. It's fully manual so it's a bit of a ritual chore, but some things are worth the journey so I'm not complaining about that at all.
It doesn't appear to be super-easy to clean, though I have not attempted it just yet. I've been grinding the same beans and I can tap out most of the residual, but I'm sure I'm already getting some eye-rolls about needing to clear out any lingering oils and whatnot.
The drawbacks are, the new owner registration is too happy for my tastes (I literally asked to NOT get any more emails during the signup, but I see there is more online content on their website than I would have thought for a manual coffee grinder). I will need to see how to clean this thing but I'm not looking forward to returning to their website.
And, it's slightly expensive now that I had a look around and see what looks like the same exact device (so they OEM it, I assume) for less and even much less. Would I get the same results sans touchy-feeling customer experience and at a lower price?
It's priced so that getting another one for grinding your flax seeds or other non-coffee dry goods would be completely reasonable, so maybe I could try that out and see how it goes.
As is, though, it does precisely what I hoped it would and it appears to do it well.

Does a great job of grinding for a french press. I don't mind the manual work; it makes the coffee that much more rewarding, but the stainless steel cylinder can be slippery. I have a pretty tough grip but I found the grinder slipping a little too often. A couple pieces of grip tape or talon grip tape take care of it no problem, but it would be awesome if there was a little bit of stippling around the grippy parts.

Used daily now for 8 months. Sometimes twice a day. So far it has worked almost flawlessly.
Set it to fine grain which takes longer to grind but it loosens up to a coarser grain after a couple weeks. I found just leaving it where it wants to be works well for my French Press. No more clogged screens or difficulty pushing the plunger down. The French Press cleans easily and quickly.
2 tablespoons of coffee beans takes 4-5 minutes to grind. It is my early morning workout to loosen the shoulders. Walk into the kids bedrooms to wake them up while grinding away. They wake less cheerful as they age.
Only a couple minor issues.
1. Fine setting does not stay in place. The wheel loosens a half turn or so but it still grinds small enough for a French Press.
2. Always spills a little bit on the counter. No matter how careful I am.

Overall I highly recommend this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: A good grinder for the price
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is not extremely precise as the grinder can be slightly tilted but it gives you enough control to get very close to the grind you need, especially for the price. The coarseness is set with a turn screw, not with any fixed settings, so you have to experiment a little to find the right grind but it's not a big deal. The overall aesthetic is nice, the build quality seems good, and the act of hand-grinding for your cup is enjoyable. It's max capacity is about 32 grams which you can grind in about the same time it takes to heat up your water.

If youre looking for a grinder which will have you manually grinding coffee in the early morning while youre half asleep and wishing youd have bought an automatic grinder then this is what youre looking for. In the morning, after I get out of bed, beard and hair disheveled I looked forward to groggily walking to my kitchen and getting out my scale to weigh the amount of coffee I will be using with my hipster chemex brewer. As I manually crank away I feel regret that I did not splurge and get that automatic grinder to make this chore easier. However after having my coffee I feel a sense of accomplishment knowing that I made this coffee.

Nice solid, sleek construction. There is something beautiful, timeless really, about making a personal cup of coffee with this manual grinder. My intent with getting this grinder was to really connect with the process of making my morning coffee (that had become routine) by making a truly perfect cup of coffee that would allow me to really experience this blessing to mankind again in a simple and pure way right in my home (or office) in a city saturated with subpar coffee shops. In the short time I have had this grinder it has already helped me achieve a much more satisfying, full bodied flavor in my cup. The other thing that led me to take the time and endorse this product, is the companies assistance online. Once you have the grinder, the website is very helpful in understanding the coffee experience more fully, while explaining in detail about the use/care/maintenance of the little grinder. Very solid. I am thankful for what I now own and for what I a have learned online through this companies site.

Been using this grinder for about 3 weeks. So far, so good. Very happy with the purchase. Perfect for my one liter French Press.
I have a plug-in burr grinder that I haven't used since I got this hand-crank one.... :)

JavaPresse: You should add your very helpful response (to a customer's question) in to your "instruction manual". I remembered reading it when I made the purchase, and came back to Amazon just to get the suggested clicks.
-----------------------------
As far as the number of clicks for each grind size, here are a few additional guidelines from our team of baristas for you to follow.
Turn the adjustment knob all the way to the right. Each number below represents a "click" to the left.
Coarse: 13-18
Medium Coarse: 10-12
Medium: 7-9
Medium Fine: 4-6
Extra Fine: 1-3
The art of hand grinding your coffee includes finding the perfect size for your preferences, so use these as a starting point to create your own unique brew.
-----------------------------

I have had this mill for a month now. Everything is still working as well as it did when I got it. It arrived well packaged, was simple to figure out how to use and set the grind level and even had some handy dandy video links to watch for best operation, grinds and cleaning. I use it every day to make my single cup of coffee and it took less time to grind the beans than I had expected. (About 2-3) minutes. I am not sure I'd want to do this if I was making more coffee, but for me it is perfect. I'm getting ready to go abroad for a year and am taking this along with my Aeropress (mill fits inside of it nicely). I would buy this again and would recommend to anyone. AND my coffee was much better than it was with my $45 electric grinder - that kept jamming.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works as advertised and makes better-tasting coffee than my electric blade grinder
reviews.reviewText:
I'm enjoying the product. So far it seems well-built and makes better-tasting coffee in my french press than my electric blade grinder did. I've seen complaints here about the time it takes to grind. Well, that's how burr grinders work. It only takes a few minutes to grind a full load in there and that's good for two large coffee cups of regular-strength coffee or one strong one.

If you want a hands-free grind, or need more capacity there are electric burr grinders available or you can pre-cook the flavor out of your beans using a high-speed blade grinder like I used to. Your choice. :D

There's definitely a learning curve when it comes to learning how to disassemble/reassemble this thing. Today I went to grind up my morning coffee for the french press, as usual, and for some reason it wasn't working. Cue near-meltdown because mama NEEDS her coffee! Luckily my significant other was home and he was able to figure out that I'd somehow managed to dislodge the inner chamber that holds the ceramic outer part of the grinder. (I don't know what any of the individual pieces are called, please bear with me.) Inside of the outer metal sleeve there is a black plastic sleeve that helps to hold the outer ceramic ring in place. I think maybe the black sleeve is normally glued in, but somehow mine had come out, and my attempts at grinding just spun this inner sleeve in circles without grinding a dang thing. After cleaning it out with the trusty qtip technique demonstrated on the website, he was able to line up the pieces correctly to keep them in place, and voila! My coffee grinder is cleaner and more functional than ever! Now I know what I'm working with so I can handle it if it happens again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quality is lacking. Lasted until 2 days after return window closed.
reviews.reviewText: I wanted to like this hand coffee grinder. But, the quality is lacking. I ordered August 26, received August 28. Tonight (September 28) the item stopped working. The ceramic burr became stuck and no longer grinds. I realize the price is low, but 1 month is unacceptable. I'll be contacting the manufacturer, and depending on the response I may update this review to reflect the customer service experience.

I use this to make 1 serving of coffee (400 grams of water) every morning, I use 20 grams of beans and it takes me 2-3 minutes to grind it all at a fairly course setting for pour over coffee. I have not used any finer settings than pour over but I am very pleased with the course grind for pour over. I wrapped the top and bottom section with a strip of athletic tape to make it easier to grip while grinding.

reviews.reviewTitle: Durable and convenient if no electricity is available
reviews.reviewText:
Great to have for camping trips or situations where you may not have electricity to grind fresh coffee.

My fiance and I are religious coffee drinkers and started enjoying fresh grounded coffee, so we needed a coffee grinder.

When first purchasing this grinder, we were excited and thought it was great to have a new kitchen tool to grind our fresh coffee.

However, overtime and in hindsight, it may have been more practical for us to get an electronic coffee grinder as this manual coffee grinder takes awhile to grind manually for the yield it produces.

Overall, this product is great quality and convenient for situations where you don't have electricity, but may not be the best purchase if you're looking for quick yielding of coffee grinds.

reviews.reviewTitle: so here's my short and sweet take. If you want better coffee
reviews.reviewText:
There's a few reviews on this, so here's my short and sweet take.

If you want better coffee, this is the better way to go. There was a noticeable difference the flavor of my coffee (granted I hadn't cleaned my grinder in awhile [KRUPS, had for years, just keeps going], but wouldn't have made that much difference). Did a test grind per recommended, and made a slight adjustment and got a nice grind.

Pros: Easy to use, simple to adjust. Got 5 cups from it, which is my coffee maker maxes out at, so that was perfect. Wasn't hard to manually grind the coffee, and quiet.

Cons: Took about 5 minutes to grind. Didn't notice any marks to show where you are at on the adjustments (so when you find that nice grind, easiest to keep it).

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't think about it - just buy it!
reviews.reviewText:
It took a while before I could test this awesome little mechanical device out but I can tell you that it's a very High Quality coffee grinder and is a welcome addition to my backpack when I go camping and - if need be - for when we lose power due to a winter or summer storm in New England!

Somehow, these folks tweaked this thing to make proper sized coffee grains resulting in the perfect brew.

I'd buy it again and will likely buy another for a present to a family member!

This is a solid piece of gear... I wouldn't hesitate to buy it now that I have bought it and used it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Only worked for a couple grinds
reviews.reviewText: It only worked for a couple grinds and then the mechanism developed a wobble and the grind got really uneven. Cannot recommend.

Ok, so I like it. But.... If you want to grind coffee for espresso, it's going to take you a LONG time to grind enough, fine enough, to make a double shot. I got bored with cranking and cranking and cranking... so I gave it to my 8 y/o. He thought it was fun for a while, but then became bored and didn't want to do it anymore. So I improvised. The crank comes off so you can open it up and add beans. The "nut" that the crank hooks up to is 6 sided just like a bit for my cordless drill... HEY! There's an idea! When my wife and I both want espresso, I fill everything up, take out the cordless drill and spin it on low speed for a while till the bottom fills up. Still takes about 10 minutes.

My wife and I just started roasting our own coffee in small batches and we were unhappy with our old cheap coffee mill that whirred the coffee into dust that clogged filter screens. So, I bought a countertop mill for my wife and I bought the JavaPresse for me. My wife finds a coffee that she likes and sticks with it. I like to experiment. I bought 12 different types of green coffee beans to roast and Im rotating through them. The great thing about the JavaPresse is that you put just enough in for the amount of coffee you want. I prefer mine, one cup at a time. Its simple. The mill is very solid and well made. I like the feel of it as it grinds the beans. I highly recommend purchasing!

reviews.reviewTitle: I was able to produce a cup of excellent coffee after a few grind experiments
reviews.reviewText:
Really looking forward to my first coffee grinder. When the product arrived it looked promising. Even though I could never hear/feel the clicks, I was able to produce a cup of excellent coffee after a few grind experiments. However, after using it about every other day for just two weeks, I started noticing uneven grinds. A fine to medium fine setting yields ground sizes ranging from powders to 1/8 a bean. The grinder itself is definitely off axis, with one side almost kissing the rim and the other side a gaping hole in between, and I've even begun to suspect that the grinder loosened as I was grinding because the grounds that came out later were coarser than when it started ... Now, I've been using it to do pour overs, so the coffee I make with it is still passable for now (with a tinge of sour in an otherwise flavorful cup -_-), but I have already started looking for another grinder

Edited to Add: Troubleshooted tonight and discovered that I had put the adjustment knob backwards after my first cleaning ... I can feel the clicks now :). Will update in a week or two on whether I'm still experiencing the above mentioned problems.

Just began my journey as a coffee connoisseur and thought I would go the purist route and get a manual grinder. NOT!!!!. Tried to hold out as long as I could, but just the act of churning the handle every morning got a bit old. (Not to mention if a second cup was desired!!!!). Portability is of course king with this grinder. The composite conical burr does its job. I just dont know if I would be so anal as to need to grind my own beans while on vacation. Surely theres a Starbucks somewhere near your next vacation spot! All in all, does its job, just a bit of a GRIND...(SORRY.....couldnt help it :)

reviews.reviewTitle: This was the missing ingredient to our perfect cup of coffee!
reviews.reviewText: We love our new coffee grinder. We have been using an electric one in the past and the beans were never evenly ground up. I didnt realize how much of a difference it makes in the coffee to have them ground properly. This grinder is very easy to use and grinds the beans evenly so you can get a nice strong cup of coffee. In fact, we are going to even start using less beans now because with this grinder ALL the beans get ground well. There arent some that are half ground up. A half ground bean doesnt release as much flavor. Lesson learned! Amazing customer service too. Very pleased.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'm completely satisfied with this purchase
reviews.reviewText: I'm completely satisfied with this purchase. I've only used the grinder a few times at this point, but it performs exactly as advertised. I'm happy that I bought this all-aluminum product as opposed the the competitors with glass or plastic receptacles, and I like its slender design for storage efficiency. It definitely yields a more consistent grind than the blade grinder I was using. Whether this leads to a better cup of coffee I can't say since my palate isn't quite that refined. But it requires little enough effort to get the benefits that the coffeeverse believes are there that I'll continue to use it and assume I'm getting them. Customer service appears to be first-rate.

This product worked well for me while it actually worked. I purchased the burr grinder in order to get a more consistent coarse grind for brewing french press coffee. It worked great for the first few days and provided a good quality consistent grind. After a few uses though, it started jamming and now will no longer grind. I followed the instructions that came with it, but they seemed pretty vague. I certainly would not rule out user error but the knob keeps unscrewing instead of clicking to the right or left and when I try to turn the lever it now twists the whole plastic insert rather than grind the beans. If anyone has any advice that would be great!

Update: Great customer service resolved the issue! Back to drinking some great coffee!

I've been using a Keurig and just got to the point where tossing the non-recyclable pods just seemed too wasteful. My son has been talking coffees and preparations and I felt I was missing something. Taking the time to bring the water to a boil, measure and grind the beans have turned into a small ritual. I find myself taking time to savor what it's taken a little bit more of an effort to prepare. Now I'm using the Durapresse Conical Burr Grinder and the Durapresse Pourover Dripper with delicious coffee results. It's great for traveling - I went to visit my daughter to help her move into a new apartment; all her belongings were packed - no worries! with my grinder and dripper, we had all we needed. I bought another for my son - couldn't wait for Christmas - and he's a fan, too. Love this product - thank you!

This is a great little grinder for brewing 1-2 cups of coffee. It ground the beans very well as long as you use good quality beans. Cheap beans did not work well. The high quality beans I got directly from Kona, Hawaii made a fabulous cup of coffee. The only issue I have is due to the arthritis is my hands. I had to use a rubber gripper for opening lids on jars to get a good grip on the cylinder while grinding. Also, if youre needing a grinder for large pots of coffee, this probably will not suit your needs. Since Im the only coffee drinker in my home, its perfect for me.

Grinding enough beans for a pot of coffee (750 ml) takes 3-4 minutes. I'm fairly strong, and this is significant effort for me. I have average size guy hands and the grinder is too small to grip comfortably. The grinder top fits into the base that receives the ground coffee by friction fit only, so the force of grinding can cause the top to turn in the base. It needs a countertop base so it doesn't have to be held during grinding, some sort of grip to make it comfortable and a little brush to get the powdery coffee out of the base. I'm keeping it, but wouldn't have purchased if I had tired it first. On the plus side, it does produce a consistent grind and it was cheap.

reviews.reviewTitle: Use a drill to spin it clockwise. I just save you a ton of time...
reviews.reviewText: Best advice is to use a cordless drill instead of the handle. Have been watching my wife use this thing and spin it clockwise by hand for a month or two. She gave it to me a couple of times to do for a while. We do Chia and flax seed with it. I looked at it the other day and said I have an idea. Used my drill. Turned a 30 min job in to a 30 second job. Works flawlessly.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very Solid Coffee Grinder, grinds nice and fine
reviews.reviewText: Fresh ground coffee is always better than pre-grounded. However grinding myself one cup requires a ton of cranks, a lot more than I expected. it could take a good few minutes of spinning away at the handle to get just a little bit of beans ground. I don't mind doing it for myself, but if someone else comes over, it does almost feel like a chore. In other words I kind of wish I bought an electrical one. However I've heard the electric ones in this price range aren't very good.

Great product. Just not for me. The coffee resulting from the time spent grinding was delicious! However, I decided that I do not have the patience to grind that long or much for each cup of coffee. Plus I add sweetener and/or creamer anyway, so I decided to just buy the already ground version of the coffee.
That being said, the grinder works great. It is easy to use, easy to clean, nice and compact, and seems sturdy. If I ever decide that I have the patience to grind beans, I'll buy this again.
I would recommend this to my more patient friends.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Value With Three Minor Quibbles
reviews.reviewText:
After recently kicking my soda habit and replacing it with coffee, I've begun to explore the world of coffee snobbery  without becoming a snob, and without spending Jeff Bezos amounts of money. That is what led me to the somewhat Zen-like practice of manually grinding whole beans and, thus, to the JavaPresse.

If you're currently all jacked up on caffeine with hundreds of things to do and no patience for reading, I will summarize by saying that this is a worthy, affordable purchase and it will serve you well. It will also make you, as you walk around the office grinding beans, feel superior to all the lesser humans sipping on their instant coffee, energy drinks and/or hard alcohol.

If, however, you have a bit of time then I'll outline the three aforementioned quibbles:

1) Powdered plastic after a grind session. In the attached photos, you'll find before/after shots of the top of the grind axle. You can see a fine, white powder that shows up after grinding. I'm assuming this is a result of friction between the plastic washer and the metal bolt. While I don't fancy consuming plastic, I'm not overly concerned since I could eat the entire washer with no probable ill effects. If teens can survive Tide pods, a few micrograms of plastic is inconsequential.

2) Slightly-offset axle alignment. Also in the attached photos, you'll see two shots of the floating burr. At 180 degrees apart, the distance from the floating burr to the mounted burr differs by a moderate amount. The result is a less than perfectly-consistent grind size. I imagine that engineering a perfectly aligned grind axle would increase the cost of the JavaPresse by a significant margin. I'd estimate that only the elite upper 3% of coffee drinkers would consider this a major flaw and turn up their pretentious noses to it (Im looking at you, avocado toast-eating Millenials from California). It's only a very minor annoyance to the shadow of my subconscious perfectionist.

3) Inconsistently-floating floating burr. This is what annoys me the most. In the last photo, you'll see circled in red where the burr has too much room to float on the plastic X-shaped insert upon which it is mounted. There is a spring that puts pressure on the plastic sleeve to keep it at a consistent distance from the housing, but because the floating burr has so much room to move on the insert, it often gets stuck at a distance I don't want it at. During the first few days of use I occasionally ended up with espresso powder because the burr had gotten stuck too far up. I've forged the habit of checking the burr before each use and, if necessary, pulling it down to ensure it's flush with the plastic insert.

Despite these things, I am happy with the JavaPresse and look forward to its continued use (I use a medium-ish grind with a reusable K-cup...much success). I can recommend it to anyone looking to step up their enjoyment of coffee without spending excessively.

I bought this to use as a spice grinder. I like to buy whole spices and grind them as needed. The Javapresse grinder does a good job of this. The durability is unknown, but it is well built so that shouldn't be issue.

I watched the video on the Javapresse website demonstrating how to use the grinder. The video was useful, but didn't answer the only question I had. How do you hold the shaft still while adjusting grind? I found that I had to attach the handle to hold the shaft in place while adjusting the grind. The demonstrator didn't appear to do this or anything, he just spun the black adjustment knob.

reviews.reviewTitle: Allows me to make coffee in late night 300 times
reviews.reviewText:
Manual coffee grinders are great if you are living with others in the same building because you can make fresh coffee from whole beans in late night or early morning without disturbing them.

I should have got JavaPresse Manual Coffee Grinder much earlier. I have used an antique one but it was not easy to grind coffee beans even just for a single cup. This one is much easier and I can make 4-6 cups (2-3 mugs) of coffee every day. It's been six months since I got this so I have made 300 mugs of coffee and it still works perfectly. But it can be a little better--I hope the next version is shorter and fatter with a bigger handle.

Getting French Press Grind without a very expensive "power" grinder is great. I am an occasional user for a couple cups at a time. The JavaPresse is perfect for me. I get consistent grind with dial in perfection. My grandson recommended the JavaPresse and would never lead me astray. The unit is very easy to load with beans and hold while grinding. It has consistent solid feel and with a little shaking occasionally you know when the grind is finished. Highly recommended. I am in the occasional cleaning mode, but don't see its a big problem. Resetting the grind keeps me from "regular" cleaning.

reviews.reviewTitle: A Coffee Grinder to be Enjoyed for Generations to Come....
reviews.reviewText: So glad I purchased this coffee grinder from JavaPresse. I use it every morning when I make my coffee and it grinds those little beans down to little grains of sweet, sweet caffeine nectar that I need to wake my weary soul up. The grinder itself is high quality, well made and durable. I plan on passing this coffee grinder down to my children and my childrens children, and my childrens children children and so on. I believe the quality and durability will last for ages and what makes me happy is knowing that this coffee grinder will be around for centuries....that way the first thing my offspring will think of in the morning is ME as they grind their coffee beans with the very same coffee grinder that I used to grind my coffee beans...how unbelievable is that?? However, I am now realizing a problem with this coffee grinder....I have two children....when they get married and have children, what if they each have two children...then that will be a total of six of my offspring but only one JavaPresse Coffee grinder....will only one child inherit the coffee grinder....perhaps the eldest should inherit it...and give it to their eldest and so on....not sure how to tackle this problem. Hhhhmmmm....I think I'm just going to purchase 12 more manual coffee grinders from JavaPresse and use a different one every morning...that way everyone stays happy and the family does not get torn apart due to infighting over my very durable and long lasting coffee grinder made by the fabulous folks at JavaPresse!!

First time using a grinder to make my own grinds from whole bean coffee. The process is straightforward and the build quality seems to be quite good. So far I've made probably a dozen or so grinds and there don't appear to be any unusual wear with the product.

Only have 2 real complaints or objects of note with the product.

1) It is possible to turn the adjustment knob at the bottom beyond fine. So if you're like me and you follow the instructions that say turn to the right until it stops. You will turn it way too fa. A better instruction would be "turn to the right until it takes more force than previous turns" or something of the sort. Once you figure that out it's all pretty straight forward.

2) One side of the grinder could stand to be flat. When you remove the cup from the bottom there's no side of the grinder to lay it on. (The top has the penta rod for the handle and the bottom has the grinder). If you place it on it's side it wants to roll off the table.

Number 2 is a really minor thing. And number 1 is mostly me being inept. 5 stars. Would recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: Takes a while to grind beans, but eventually gives as good of a grind as any other Burr grinder I have used.
reviews.reviewText: I bought this as a last resort to spending $150+ on a Burr Electric grinder. It had great reviews so I jumped in. Overall it has a good build, looks nice, and it functional. I drink a 12-16oz glass of coffee every morning and I grind either 4 or 5 TBSP of beans. 6 TBSP is the most it will hold. If you load 4 or 5 TBSP it takes about 2-3 minutes to grind it all. However, it is a far superior grind to a standard coffee grinder. If you have the money, splurge for the electric Burr grinders. But if you are in a pinch, this will do fine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Seems like quality. Parts fit and function well
reviews.reviewText:
Product arrived quickly.Instructions told me what I needed to know.Seems like quality.Parts fit and function well.Ihave an AeroPress. Grind seems fine.I did not change it.
It does not require much torque,or strength,to crank the handle.Its low effort enough I can't imagine breaking anything.
I have had no requirement for customer service,but JavaPresse seems quite interested in me being a happy customer.
Now,the overall performance impression. "Good,cheap(inexpensive) ,fast;Pick any two" Its good,its inexpensive. Its not fast. But heating your water will give enough time,probably.Its an alternative to watching the pot.
But,getting realistic,its very compact.It will fit inside the AeroPress plunger. It does all it promises to do. With an Esbit tablet stove or a Trangia alchohol burner ,I can start some water heating. I COULD use instant coffee.......Or I can drop some select beans in this grinder and produce an exceptional coffee for myself and a guest in any setting,from lakeside to woods to hotel room to interstate rest area to "Netflix and Chill"
You can think of grinding the beans as part of the "Tea Ritual".
It may not be best for the daily morning cup....not for everyone..You can get an electric grinder or grind your beans at the store..
But it will provide you with "That special cup"

reviews.reviewTitle: Good enough for a coffee snob!
reviews.reviewText:
I've been a coffee lover for years, and while working as a barista, learned a lot about the techniques (weight, grind, different brewing methods) to get a great cup of coffee. So when I say that I've become a coffee snob, I'm not over exaggerating!

That being said, this grinder is great. This is the first manual grinder I have ever tried, but I am impressed! I was grinding my coffee using an electric commercial burr grinder at a coffee shop, but that requires grinding the whole bag vs. freshly grinding per brew (which yields a tastier and more robust cup). I grind for French press, and after getting the proper grind setting, it ground consistently coarse beans for me. Best French press cup I've had! Thanks javaPresse!!

Notes:
- reasonably priced
- quiet- just a crunchy sound of beans being ground and it's pretty cathartic
- easier than I thought it would be to manually grind. Just tap the bottom lightly on the counter a few times to get the best outcome
-Doesn't take up a lot of counter space, and easy to travel with if needed
-easy to dismantle to clean
- window is nice so you can view the grounds to make sure they're the right size
-javapresse has helpful vids to maximize usage and maintenance

Only reason I gave four stars instead of five is because the hopper is kinda small (couldn't fit all 64g of beans at once), and it does take some time to grind, but anything great is worth the time and patience! :)

reviews.reviewTitle: Works perfectly, once you figure out how to set the grind size.
reviews.reviewText: Taught myself how to make pour-over coffee and the JavaPresse grinder is a key ingredient of the entire process. Once you figure out the proper coffee grind size for your style of coffee, and you set the ceramic grinder, this unit works like a champ. There are online videos you can watch and JavaPresse provides you with all kinds of wonderful information on the proper brewing and selection of coffee. I love my JavaPresse and really enjoy the grinding and brewing process. It's fast, efficient and perfect for making a great cup of fresh coffee.

First and most importantly, this grinder does the job of grinding beans. I set mine to a coarser bring for a French press or percolator. In terms of consistency, I was very pleased. My electric blade grinder has always been very inconsistent in size, so this was refreshing. Its not a very large grinder so it seems like it would be good for travel/camping.
