It will hold plenty of beans to make at least 16oz of coffee. However, this contributes to my only complaint. The hopper open is very small, especially with the grinding mechanism sticking out of it, so its difficult to get beans into it without them going all over. The grind select seems to work fine but in order to get it set correctly, you have to close it all the way (Turkish grind) and then open it the specified number of clicks from there. On a coarse grind setting, it takes about 3 minutes to grind a full hopper at a moderate pace. But lets face it, if youre upset about the time/effort it takes to grind your beans, stop being cheap and get an electric grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: it is ok product but it can be better
reviews.reviewText:
I have used this product for several days now. Depending on my experiment with this product I gave it 3 stars for following reasons:
1. Although metal parts and burrs are very solid and well-made plastic parts are made of low quality plastic. Right out of box bumps on the bottom plastic part of the burr were wear off. therefore when you turn the adjustment nub cannot feel the click to adjust the grind.
2. there are 2 identical plastic washers on top and bottom of the main shaft with a square key on one side of them. On the top, the square key fits in its place. but there is a circular hole at the bottom that makes the washer wobble in side it resulting to an unstable shaft.
3. metal washer which holds the spring inside squeezes the plastic that holds conical burr which makes it wobble even more. (although you can fix this by putting the washer upside down that reduces the movement of ceramic burr inside the plastic holder.)
4. After adjusting the lower burr to fine size to get a better consistency of grind, I realized the burr is still wobbling and also main shaft stands in an odd angle that makes upper and lower ceramic part contact on one side and have a gap between on the other side. this results in an inconsistent grind and reduces the life of ceramic burrs.
5. On the fine adjustment, ground coffee goes between main shaft and plastic holder and makes it hard to take out the lower burr for cleaning.
6. its hard to adjust the grinder. there is no indicator for adjustment. Especially if you like to switch between different brewing technics. (drip, french press, espresso, syphon).
7. It takes about 7 to 10 min depending on the adjustment to grind a decent amount of coffee for 3 to 4 cup of coffee to enjoy with family. I know it's a manual grinder but still, it seems it takes for ever. Especially after a few minutes?, my hand starts hurting because of holding the grinder firmly in hand while turning the handle.

I hope this review helps the company to realize their product weaknesses and customers to decide about buying this product.

reviews.reviewTitle: I feel less like I bought a product and more like I made an investment.
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder is, well, fun. It's very well made, easy to use, and it actually puts a smile on my face to grind my coffee. The materials that came in the box were easy to read, and provided all of the specifics for using the grinder, as well as info on videos and other multi-media.

I've been very happy with the product, service, and overall company leadership since I first purchased this product. The owners are responsive to my inquiries, and take an active role in customer service.

I feel less like I bought a product and more like I made an investment.

reviews.reviewTitle: Exactly what I was looking for
reviews.reviewText: This is an amazing manual grinder that allows me to make an excellent espresso in my Via Venezia espresso machine. My old grinder broke, which was electric and costly. I looked first for an electric grinder to replace it with, but couldn't find one within the price range I was willing to spend that jumped out at me. So, I thought I would use this until I found one that did. I'm stopping my search for an electric grinder, as this one fulfills me needs. I probably wouldn't want to use it to grind for a large crowd, but for me, my husband, and the occasional guests, it's perfect.

reviews.reviewTitle: which is perfect as counter space is a premium in my kitchen
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using this coffee grinder for about a month now, and I am really loving the coffee I make with it! Grinding does not take too much force; it's very light-weight and compact, which is perfect as counter space is a premium in my kitchen!

At first, I had my reservations after reading some reviews from customers who had experienced some defect in the product (e.g., broken handle). I also recall seeing some other reviews citing issues with inconsistent size of grounds when using the coarser settings.

I do have my grinder set for coarser grounds (I use a french press), and while I do see some inconsistency in size of grounds, they are a heckuvalot more consistent than what I was getting with my old blade grinder! From doing research on burr grinders, it seems inconsistency in the size of coffee grounds is a common issue among many burr grinders. And, I definitely do not have the budget for a thousand-dollar high-end burr grinder to take up highly-valuable counter space!

In summary, I'm really enjoying this grinder, and I hope to keep using it for many years!

(With update)Grinds coffee nicely, doesnt take forever. I wish the drive head that the handle slips onto was a standard (or metric) hex size, so i could easily use a socket and cordless drill to grind my coffee if i was feeling lazy. As it is, its just a little too big or small for all of my sockets. Oh well. Much more consistent grind than bladed grinders, and adjustable. Two big pluses there. With this and a French press, you will have the richest coffee in town without breaking the bank. A year and a half later, (once a week use or less) grinder broke during coffee grinding. Not so pleased anymore, shoulda got a super cheap grinder instead...

reviews.reviewTitle: Consistent grind for the price of a little squeak!
reviews.reviewText:
Purchased: May 2019
Reviewed: November 2019
3*Ok, 4*Good, 5*Great
Made in ???

Great grinder. A group of 3 to 5 of us use this almost every workday. Compared to our old bur grinder, this one is quieter with a more consistent grind. We all use different settings each day for press, pour over and making cold brew.

Update: Used nearly daily by several people. Has a little squeak to it now; however, still a consistent grind. Constantly changing the grind setting for cold brew, press, etc.

The beans coming from this device makes the best espresso ever. I came to this conclusion after trying other electric grinders. I only use it for espresso and cannot be happier with this one. The manual operation is a hassle but I do it while the machine is warming up. If you have a large family and you need to ground coffee for more than 10-12 shots, it may be too much of a hassle but it works for me. I also had a slight issue when it first arrived but the customer service was amazing. They sent me a replacement part immediately. Highly recommended. Good product. Good company.

I bought this based on the other reviews for the product. My criteria was consistency of grind. Even though JavaPresse had far less reviews than others, they were all unanimous on grind consistency. I have to tell you I was seriously doubtful based on the number of look a likes that are offered that any of them were different other than name. I obviously have not tried the others, but have no reason to. This one is perfect.
Consistent and easy to adjust grind.
Easy to load beans.
Grind rate and ease of turn is very good.
Given cleaning instructions, but I have no intention of removing the burr to clean. I have had a pepper grinder for 20 years and seen no reason to disassemble it.
I had previously bought my Daughter a more expensive "glass jar" grinder on Amazon, and was not happy with the grind rate and consistency. This little gem is far superior.

reviews.reviewTitle: and it is really easy to put together
reviews.reviewText: The grinder came in a neat box, and it is really easy to put together. The adjustment knob for the ground size is not perfect, and it is a bit wonky at first until you get used to it. This being a manual grinder, you have to be ready to put some effort to grind it. It is slightly slippery at times, and obviously you need to be holding the top portion of the grinder when you are spinning the knob. If you are consistently using one type of beans, then it's fine, but if you are swapping between several types of beans and you do not want the flavors of the beans to mix, you have to take it apart and clean it. It is a minor inconvenience, but if you are swapping between beans frequently, it may become an annoyance. By the way, you have to replace it after a while when the ceramic grinding parts become worn out, and at the price it is selling, it isn't too expensive to replace. Overall, I am satisfied with the product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great device at this price point
reviews.reviewText: I have a burr grinding coffee maker and looking for something to make a single cup in an AeroPress as well as travel/hike etc. This fits that bill perfectly. The price is right, it's easy to use and clean and looks good. If there was one thing I'd wish it had is a way to store the handle, but that's not a deal killer. I'd recommend this for anyone that is grinding beans for a single cup a couple of times a week. If you're doing large quantities, this isn't the device for you as it does about one cup's worth at a time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quality product for not a lot of money.
reviews.reviewText:
So, I bought the JavaPresse because I wanted a quality bur grinder without having to dish out a lot of money, and it delivers for the most part.

Pros:

Price

Quality feel to materials

Size - small form factor makes it perfect for
cramped kitchens like mine.

Adjustable grind - coarse to varying degrees of fine.

Disassembly - easy to take a part when you want to clean it.

Looks nice.

Cons:

Manual grinder - takes longer to grind beans than a grinder with an electric motor, obviously. I don't consider it an issue but I could see other people, rushing around in the mornin getting their kids ready for school and themselves properly caffeinated for the long day ahead; finding the longer process frustrating.

Hopper - The opening where the coffee beans go into the hopper is a bit small. I've spilled beans a couple of times now while loading the grinder, but that can't really be helped given its small size and form factor. And it's really not that big a deal as long a I take my time and don't try to rush it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worthwhile Investment for Ambitious Coffee Consumers
reviews.reviewText:
To allow for context let me explain the role of the JavaPresse Manual Coffee Grinder in my life. I use this grinder predominantly for travel and work related coffee brewing and not so much for home use. I grind the beans specifically for French press style so I can't really comment too much on the finer grinds. I've been using this grinder most days for roughly two months and prior to this purchase I either purchased ground coffee or used an electric grinder (Cuisinart Grind Central). I personally give the product an overall 5 stars for my use of it but it overall gets a 4 star for quality. I will still breakdown some of the various characteristics because it is by no means a perfect product and some of the flaws may lean other users more towards a 3 or 5 star rating.

Product size
Pros: Compact with removable lever arm. Fits well in users stabilizing hand.
Cons: Chamber is only large enough for roughly 6-8 cups of brewed coffee (more or less depending on desired strength). Larger volumes will require multiple grinds.
Take home: Ideal for grinding coffee for 1-2 people. Ideal for travel (camping, work, etc.).

Coffee Grind
Pros: Easily adjust grind to desired coarseness. Grind remains consistent throughout each individual use (see below). Really satisfying "crunch" as the coffee beens are mechanically ground. Relatively quick grind for rough coarseness (about 2-3 minutes).
Cons: Time. I've only done fine coarseness twice and both times took upwards of 5-10 minutes. Occasionally at the end of grind the last coffee bean fragments will lodge in the grinder. When this happens continued turning of the lever arm will actually tighten grinding mechanism resulting in a finer grind. If product not cleaned or adjusted in-between uses you may result in finer than anticipated grind with next use. Product advertised as having an 18 click grind selection. Though this isn't totally inaccurate it is a bit misleading as the coarseness is based off how tight or loose the plastic nut is screwed on the base of the grinding mechanism. There is no "clicking" or visible marker for which setting you are at (1 through 18 I'd presume as advertised). Grind coarseness is very much a grind a little bit then check if the coarseness is right. Adjust and repeat until satisfied.
Take home: Be ready for arm day if you are grinding for multiple people, making multiple brews, or enjoying a finer coarseness (Expresso drinkers). If you fall into this category you may want to consider an electric grinder. Ideal for French press. Should be cleaned and checked every few uses.

Value
Pros: Can obtain a consistent coarseness that may be difficult to obtain with low and middle tier electric grinders that are of equal or greater price. Product seems structurally sound with no evidence of wear and tear as of yet.
Cons: None that I foresee at the time this was written.
Take home: I would recommend this product for anyone pursuing rough coarseness consistency. Great value when compared to entry level electric grinders.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does what it's supposed to do.
reviews.reviewText:
This is an excellent manual grinder for the price. Very fine grind adjustment. Simple design. Works very well.

The reservoir fire the ground coffee is a perfect "slip-fit" over the grinding mechanism, so if you're rough with it, I can see how folks would complain that it gets loose and falls off over time. However, it's seems natural given its size that you would hold onto both the upper and lower parts just by gripping it, so I don't see this as a problem. Perhaps there could be threads on the body to screw the two parts together, but that would be a hindrance in my view as it would inevitably get clogged with coffee and be tough to unscrew, as well as increase the thickness of the walls of the cylinder; the weight of the grinder; the production cost and therefore price of the grinder.

I have used this product every morning for over a week now and I can't imagine finding a better manual burr-mill for the price.

If you need to grind a large amount of coffee in a short time, this is probably not for you.

However, if you want to hand grind enough fresh coffee to load up a 16oz French press, this is the ticket.

I would love to give this product 5 stars but there was only one thing that barred this from perfection...sharp edges. Dont get me wrong, I absolutely love this thing but what would make this a 10/10 is if they polished out a few spurs on the top cap by the handle. I know thats not an important factor but to see something that looks this premium and well built fall slightly off mark, pokes at me. The edges of the top cap were a bit sharp and almost Snagged me a few times, my fianc has actually gotten cut on it. I doubt that the sharpened edges are a normal post production thing seeing as others have given such great reviews, so Ill just chalk it down as it being just a slip during product inspection. Top cap aside, the overall build quality and design is just amazing. From the perfect ceramic teeth grinding the beans just right to the small sleek design that allows me to take it on camping trips with little to no loss in bag space, I love it, just had to sand down the rim of the top.

I used to grind coffee beans by electric blade grinder. Hoping AI technology will transform it to a smart grinder in the near future. Wrong. Or may be a little too early for AI to pay attention to a coffee bean grinder. Then JavaPress and this is MANUAL. Yes, it takes few minutes to grind, only 2-3 cups amount at a time, and you need to get used to, but I found myself enjoy doing this. The powder generated is very even, unlike electric blade generated. Aroma is great, very small amount of powder is left from the grinder and cleaning is easy. Electric blade one has substantial amount of powder stacked everywhere and feel "mottainai", etc. I really like it.

After constant daily use, the cylinder on this puppy has started to warp on me. It is what it is, fairly thin metal. I don't want to say its low quality, but I don't expect this would last for daily use past 1 or 2 years. It makes enough for one decently strong round of coffee per grind and the granules will come out fairly rough, I recommend this to be used only if you are a french press person as the grinds will not be fine enough to give you a quality pour over.

Pros: nice compact size, easy to empty/ grinds the beans

CONS: takes a long time to dial in just right, pulling it apart makes it a nightmare to figure out exactly where you left off and discourages cleaning. Setting the dial to where it /should/ be does not always mean you get what you set- sometimes coming out way way too fine, others too coarse.

Save yourself the trouble and just buy an electric one- it will save you some time and frustration.

Wasn't quite sure when I purchased this, I mean, I read the great reviews, but didn't know if it would be a hassle hand grinding the beans for my morning cup. Even though I have an ancient electric grinder, I had been primarily been buying ground coffee for a long time, and I just wasn't loving my coffee. Anyway, wow, what a coffee improvement, JavaPresse Manual Burr Grinder is terrific - seriously such a better cup of coffee! Who knew? Well, apparently everyone but me! It's super easy to use, and doesn't take all that long (maybe two easy minutes) to grind up the beans for large single cup. So glad I read the positive reviews and took a chance! Very pleased with this purchase!

Bought this manual grinder to make French press coffee. After some experimentation, got a nice coarse grind, per the recipe. As others have noted, it takes time to grind even a quarter cup of beans. Perhaps we have been spoiled by electric blade grinders? Followed the French press instructions to the letter. They yielded a cup of weak, tepid, tasteless coffee. So, back to the single cup fine grind coffee approach, in my gold filter. Will try this grinder for the fine grind, and compare it to the blade grinder. Since they both are likely to yield the same product, will probably choose twenty-five seconds over several minutes of manual cranking. Product simple and as advertised. Portable too.

This is an awesome Burr coffee mill. Beautiful, top quality easy to use, infinitely adjustable. You will never have better tasting, more enjoyable coffee when grinding fresh beans. I brew in a Bellemain French Press and the combination of that and freshly ground beans from Javapresse is an unbeatable combination. Can't believe I allowed myself to suffer so many years with bitter, flat, unsatisfying Mr.Coffee brewed coffee. not to mention a landfill full of no longer working Mr. Coffee's that I and others through the years have discarded.

It works and it quiet and convenient, but you have to grip the metal center so hard that it's hard to keep using without taking breaks. The actual grinding is not difficult at all, it's keeping a hold of the actual metal center. I also tried to see if it would be easier to hold just the top part of it, but the bottom container (which holds the freshly ground coffee) slid right off and spilled coffee all over me and the floor. I also have a hard time counting the clicks because mine only clicks about 4 times before it turns completely smoothly and it is a guessing game as to how many partial rotations is a click.

Overall I think it definitely grinds very well but there are a few issues with usability. And if you have a weak grip or sweaty hands, I would definitely consider getting a rubber grip or something similar.

reviews.reviewTitle: Really glad I made this purchase
reviews.reviewText: I have another manual grinder that works well also. I bought this one at the same time to compare them. The JavaPresse grinder is a really easy tool to use to prepare freshly ground coffee. I am beginning to enjoy the three-minute ritual of grinding my own beans manually. In addition I make coffee very early in the morning and my electric coffee mill is quite loud. The JavaPresse manual grinder allows me to prepare freshly ground coffee quietly without waking everybody else. Because it is narrow and made from metal, I am confident taking it with me when traveling to ensure I get freshly ground coffee while away.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great, can easily be used by persons with mild-moderate finger arthritis
reviews.reviewText: So, I wanted to grind my coffee and my electric grinder was just way TOO loud to use in the morning if others are sleeping. This does require a lot of spinning to grind my coffee as I like a full bodied cup of java in the morning. I'm 64 with significant arthritis and can operate this. In fact, it feels like good exercise for my hands every morning as I loosen my joints. Finally, storage is a breeze as I pull the handle off and set it on my whole bean container and then this cylinder sets next to it out of the way. We have two and use one at a cabin where space is a premium. It spins with just enough resistance to offer my fingers a good morning workout.....

Not a bad grinder...But. After trying to adjust it to the perfect grind, I still kept getting larger pieces of coffee bean in the grind. At first I thought that it wasn't adjusted properly, but after adjusting it and finally not getting the large pieces, the overall grind was way too fine. Finally upon inspection, the grinding wheel is off center allowing on one side larger pieces to fall through without getting the proper grind. Kind of disappointing.

After seeing tons of automatic conical burr grinders that were way out of my price range, I went with JavaPresse's manual one to save some money. The grinder itself is solid; it takes some work to get your beans but I love the different grind settings (I use this to grind for cold brew, French press, and drip) and it's relatively easy to clean. After almost a year of use, however, I reassembled it after cleaning to find that it wasn't functioning. I reached out to JavaPresse customer service, who directed me to instructions on their website about reassembly, which was useful (there are small pieces and it's hard to remember which direction they go sometimes. My grinder, however, still wasn't working quite right--it would grind, but it would be a very uneven grind and beans were getting caught. I reached out to JavaPresse again, to see if maybe they could replace some of the inner pieces, and they offered to send me a completely new grinder for free! I am blown away by this, and I am very excited to have the same grinder again.

On workdays, I go the lazy route and drink my drip-pot-pre-ground-whatever's-in-the-cabinet-coffee. But, my off-days are more special than that. So, in celebration of my free time, I take the extra time and effort to get out the moka pot along with my new JavaPresse Manual Coffee Grinder. Put these two pieces of the puzzle together and WOW do you get a different kind of morning coffee experience! When I first saw the picture of this product I was concerned that the handle may be made of cheap metal, but the whole grinder is made very well. I like my coffee ground to powder and this grinder (with easy adjustment) does just that. The only problem I have is that my early-morning arm gets tired while manually grinding my beans. But, hey, that's no fault of the grinder! Would I buy this product again? Definitely!

reviews.reviewTitle: Best for the money hands down!
reviews.reviewText:
I mainly use it for a pour over v-60.
I want to say I've used it around 45 times give or take 5 or 6. Every time it has produced a consistent grind. It is ver well made. The only down side is if you are making several cups for a group of friends at once. Both of your arms will be exhausted. You can always make them grind their portion of coffee to get around it though! I would very highly recommend this. There isnt a better product for the money anywhere else!

I purchased this coffee grinder fairly recently and have used it a handful of times for grinding dried herbs, flowers and/or salt. I like it reasonably well for that purpose. For large pieces of dried herbs I've found that it's helpful to pre-grind them with a mortar & pestle and then use this coffee grinder to get a more even flake size for the entire batch.

We've been washing this coffee grinder after every use. Apparently letting it air dry next to the sink isn't a good idea. Rust has begun to form on the handle. This feels like it was our mistake, so I won't return it. But for a tool that advertises itself as lasting a very long time I expected higher quality.

Using same coffee, same amount of grounds, same filtered water, same mug, same everything - it all just tastes better. After 3 days and 6 cups (primarily b/c I was messing about with it), I am now using half the sweetener I used to. It's just better.

Update: It's now been a month and a half using this about 2-3 times a week. It's great. It's now part of my morning routine - I grind the coffee while the water's boiling on the stove. Feeding it full of coffee beans, it makes about 20oz of finished coffee.

Smooth and easy grind. Finally able to get a good, even course grind which, I've never been able to get with a blade grinder.

The price is great. I'm sure there are electronic burr grinders for more but this works fine. Actually something charming to hand-grinding it yourself.

It is small. So you can probably grind out enough for one or two cups max depending on how strong you like it. Takes two or three go around for a full cold brew filter fill....but as far as getting the job done its perfect.

Great product. Would highly recommend. Also great to be able to carry it anywhere and not worry about electricity. will definitely be bringing it out to camping.

I bought this because I was looking for an affordable solution to the problem of inconsistent coffee grounds. This works somewhat better than an electric blade grinder, but the result isn't good enough in my opinion for the time or effort it takes to grind a cup's worth of beans.

Pros:
-Price
-Much quieter than an electric grinder
-Sleek, stylish, would definitely have on display
-Long handle makes it easier to grind
-Easy to adjust, clean, and disassemble

Cons:
-My biggest gripe is the inconsistency of grounds. The smaller particles make it past the mesh on my French press
-Takes a LONG time to grind, even at a coarse setting
-You have to shake the grinder to move the beans toward the burr

Overall it's decent for what it is, but I would not recommend it. Maybe I will use this as a spice grinder

reviews.reviewTitle: Not worth it...buy a higher quality grinder.
reviews.reviewText:
Well, i used it every day for two weeks at work. And today, I started getting an inconsistent grind (horribly inconsistent). Took it apart to find the burrs damaged with chipped teeth. I was going for a medium grind for pour over coffee. Im thinking, the slight wiggle in the burrs while grinding caused it. Not happy, I guess thats what I get when I go the cheapest rout.

In comparison to my Knock aergrind, the JavaPresse is a toy in a world of true tools.

reviews.reviewTitle: Coffee Really Can Make You Grow Big And Strong- If you Use THIS Grinder!
reviews.reviewText: Yes, you can grind coffee with this if you want to, but your biceps will look like Popeye's when you are finished. Probably better for smaller portions, like you would grind for spices (cloves nutmeg, mace, cinnamon, nuts, etc.) I gave up in defeat and got the Hamilton beach 80365 custom grind hands free electric coffee grinder (only to find that my old tiny Sunbeam electric one about 10 years old had begun to work again! Oh well, the Hamilton beach one DOES grind a larger amount and has more settings..) . I will save this one to use for coffee if we get a brownout due to the Zombie Apocalypse- or something.

reviews.reviewTitle: If you love coffee - this is the best $20(ish) bucks you'll ever spend
reviews.reviewText:
Next to my Chemex, this is the single best coffee-related purchase I've ever made.

I had a blade grinder for years and it was fine for a drip coffee maker, but when I upgraded to a Chemex the blade grinder sat gathering dust and I had my coffee ground at purchase because good coffee shops and decent stores that sell fresh coffee have burr grinders. Then I got hip to the fact that it's not just how the beans are ground - but when. The difference between having your beans ground hours, days, (hopefully not weeks) before brewing and grinding right before you brew - turns out to be huge. HUGE. I had no idea what I was missing.

If you're serious about your coffee - buy this. It takes a little bit of effort but is so completely worth it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good product and helpful customer service - difficult to disassemble and reassemble properly
reviews.reviewText:
It provides a much more consistent grind than the previous grinder I was using, so I'm pretty happy. It's pretty easy to use; a bit of a pain to clean (but not too bad). I have large hands, and I was unable to remove the plastic washer. But I'm sure it's fine.

I wouldn't use it if you're making coffee for more than one or two people, but it's good for a consistent grind for one person. I haven't traveled with it (and probably wouldn't), but I imagine it would fit easily into luggage if you did want to bring coffee and a grinder with you.

Customer service reached out to me to make sure all was well, which is pretty cool.

EDIT: After cleaning the thing twice, I was unable to get it back together properly. The video instructions are insufficient. The JavaPresse was cheap enough that I just went ahead and bought a cheap electric burr grinder, which seems to do the job perfectly well enough, judging by my fledgling coffee grinding experience level.

If you've got more dexterity/patience than I have, you might like this just fine if you're making coffee for just yourself. Otherwise, get a different product that's easier to disassemble.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not perfect but quite good at an excellent price
reviews.reviewText: I give this 5 stars, not because it's perfect but because it does really well for the price. This is a generic Chinese knockoff of the Porlex grinder but it's nicely constructed and has worked well for me for two months of multi-daily use. Like all these hand grinders and many electric burr grinders, the grind size is not exactly uniform. The coarser you go, the more pronounced this becomes. I grind for pour-over and always find some bigger pieces at the top of the coffee bed although not to an unacceptable degree. There are grind no settings, you simply turn an internal nut until you get the grind you want but this is extremely easy to figure out. I find it takes about 140 cranks to grind 22 g of beans to medium fine for a 3.5 minute pour-over. This is slow work, fine for yourself but not a great solution for the whole fam. I've never filled the hopper to the top but I'd think it would max out at about 30 g. One nice thing, the hopper is basically airtight so you can weigh your beans out the night before. The removable handle fits a hex rod that protrudes from the top. This seems a bit janky but has not worn noticeably in two months. Anyway, when you compare the price of the grinder with the price of a couple of lattes, it's hard to see how you could go wrong.

reviews.reviewTitle: Takes FOREVER, not for more than single cup
reviews.reviewText:
I wanted to like this, but I grind each morning 60g of beans. This took FOREVER and I had to refill the beans and dump the grinds mid way. Took a good 15min of constantly turning. I ended up using the drill hack someone posted in a review, but who wants to run a drill to operate the coffee grinder? It is nice looking, but not practical. Also the grind size is not consistent.

If you churn your own butter and spin your own wool, you will enjoy this coffee grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: JavaPresse Manual Coffee Grinder - an Excellent Product
reviews.reviewText:
Previously, I had been using an electric rotary blade grinder on my beans, but wasn't satisfied with the consistency of the grind. I had been looking at electric burr grinders, but the expensive one my son had been using died on him recently, so I was concerned with reliability, andI looked for different options.

The JavaPresse Manual Coffee Grinder caught my eye. It was very reasonably priced, and appeared to feature solid construction, so I ordered one. Before the item was even delivered, I was contacted by their customer support informing me it had shipped, and if I had any questions, I should contact them immediately.

I received the shipment promptly, and tried the mill out using the suggested setting for my AeroPress coffee brewer, and I was very impressed with the result. The grind was uniform and exactly what my AeroPress needed to brew a near perfect cup of coffee.

It takes a minute or two to grind the beans, but the end result is more than worth this minimal effort.

I contacted the company to inform them of my complete satisfaction with their product, and again received almost an immediate response in thanks. This is customer service that is unusual in my experience, and I am happy to reward a small family company both for their excellent service and for their excellent product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect for a small kitchen with limited storage
reviews.reviewText:
Sturdy, easy to clean. Perfect for small households with limited kitchen storage space.

Grinding just the right amount of fresh coffee by hand has become an enjoyable part of my morning. I love my old 4-cup percolator but it needs a coarser grind than my cheapo electric grinder can produce. Filling the chamber of the JavaPresse all the way up produces just the right amount of coarse-ground coffee for four strong cups of perked coffee. It takes about two minutes to grind and is not difficult. I'm glad I spent a bit extra for this brand and not a knock-off. It's very durable and I'm pleased I'll be able to buy replacement burr when necessary -- won't have to replace the whole unit.

The adjustment mechanism does indeed "click" when you turn it, but the levels are not marked. The manual suggests grinding a few beans and tightening or loosening as necessary. I found I quickly learned to _see_ the width of the opening that gives me the coarse grind I prefer, so I don't need trial and error every time.

If you like a fine grind I recommend starting with a coarse grind, tightening the mechanism, then regrinding. Otherwise it can be tiresome work.

Some complain that it's hard to get the beans into the hopper without spilling. I just cup my hand around the top so it acts as a funnel and spoon the beans in with a tablespoon. Problem solved.

Be sure to give the grinder a shake every few turns to move the beans around -- it makes the process faster.

This grinder is perfect for me to grind all sorts of different grinds for all the different types of coffees that I plan to make. I use to use a electric coffee grinder, but I soon realized that the grinds were very inconsistent, because I didn't the the high end one which seemed a bit to pricey for someone like me who isn't a coffee connoisseur. However, I do enjoy a great cup of coffee and this tool gets it done right the first time. Also you can change the different grind sizes by adjusting the knob under the grinder. This is accessible when you remove the bottom half of the grinder. I hope this review helped inform you enough to make a final decision. If you do decide to buy this, trust me when I say you won't be disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love the product - Customer service is unbeatable
reviews.reviewText: First of all, I love the product. It takes some experience to learn how to adjust the knob to get the grind size right, but once you do, it works well, is repeatable, and makes fantastic coffee. What is better than anything though is their customer service. I sent them an email on a weekend because I had misplaced the handle for my grinder and I wanted to know if they sold replacement parts). They responded back (within 24 hours) just to inform me that, no, they don't sell replacement parts, but they will be shipping me a whole new unit with expedited delivery. I truly cannot recommend this company enough. They have a great product and jaw-dropping customer service.

reviews.reviewTitle: What kind of sorcery is this?
reviews.reviewText:
I was shopping for burr grinders because I was sick and tired and going to my roaster for fresh coffee or generic coffee chains, and this is till I got this grinder. The instructional video was great. I thought it would be really hard to grind/spin, but it wasn't too much of an effort. Within 2-3 minutes I got the coffee powder which brewed the quality of coffee you would get at a quality roaster.

I don't know if they can make lightweight cylindrical steel burrs in the future, which could easily blow out the $$$ electrical ones.

reviews.reviewTitle: Burr jammed against the shaft in less than 2 weeks
reviews.reviewText:
It was a good product as long as it lasted but it broke after 2 weeks of use (Probably less than 20 grinds for my french press). I suffered from the same issue many people have suffered: The part that holds the burr to the shaft is made of cheap plastic and it wore out faster most likely due to the medium-coarse setting I had it in. The fact that their "replacement part" is being sold on Amazon since 2016 and they KNOW this is an issue and yet they sell the product with the original weak burr is beyond me and insulting. Now I'm stuck with a decision I did not want to make 2 weeks after purchasing this product: Change it for another grinder or buy the replacement burr.

Not a fun experience due to the unreliability but when it worked it was fine.

Been using the JavaPresse daily for a few weeks and at first the product was very sturdy. As I continued to use the JavaPress, the removable tube started to get loose and one time popped out and dropped all the coffee beans that I had grounded. Def not 5 star to me! Not sure why reviews were so high.

First, what a great price point for a conical burr grinder. Great way to experience fresh, burr ground coffee and yes, its more than hype, it literally makes coffee taste better. I am a skeptic no longer. Coffee tastes so much better through this grinder than my flat blade grinder I had been using for way too long.

Secondly, I had a issue after cleaning my machine for the first time that was completely my fault but their customer service was so understandable that they fixed me up right away. Great customer service is rare enough these days that Im always blown away when I receive it.

Thank you Javapresse!

I love using this grinder and have done so essentially every day for the past year- it has become part of my morning routine. However, the past 2 months it has become increasingly difficult to use; the handle and the bolt have both worn/stripped significantly with regular every day use, and now a year later, it is unusable.

Its a shame because Im torn between ordering another one and looking for an alternative. It would be an easy 5 stars if it was built to last!

However, if youre only going to use it on occasion, or for traveling/camping, it should last you a long time! And it does make a great cup of coffee!

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great but black insert is weak
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using this daily for about 3 months(2-4 cups a day) and the black piece is already starting to fail. It grinds the coffee great and is wonderful, but I am expecting the black plastic piece to crack any day now. The plastic piece started out very tight and the grinder stayed nice and centered. Now the black piece won't stay in and is becoming very floppy.

With that said, the grinder is very nice and makes a very consistent. I'm trying to figure out if I should upgrade to a better grinder or purchase another one of these once it breaks. I'll update once that happens.

Save your money and buy another grinder. No matter what setting or clicks you set on the grinder it just takes way too long. I tried grinding only one scoop (for one cup) thinking that it would be easier for the grinder but it didn't make any difference. I even ran it with an electric drill for several minutes but it just wouldn't grind well. I'm going to continue using my Krups blade grinder, I run it intermittently by pushing the button 10 times and not continuously. I have medium to coarse ground coffee in just a few seconds. If I want a finer grind, I do more cycles or do them longer.

I had a big problem to solve. I love good, high quality coffee, but my only option at work was Keurig (pretend this is a vomiting emoji). Obviously, this just wasn't going to cut it. But hey, I'm a bright guy, so I knew I could come up with a viable solution. After some research, I purchased this grinder, an AeroPress, and a bag of locally roasted, single origin Guatemalan coffee, and voil, all my problems were solved! Now each morning I can drink an exquisite cup of coffee as I sneer at my peasant co-workers with their pathetic Keurig coffee.. Ok, so I'm really not that mean.. I actually end up having to make several cups of coffee every morning for me and my co-workers.. But you get the point :)

This little grinder has worked great for me so far! Easy enough to fit in my desk at work, but still makes a great consistent grind, and adjusting coarseness is super easy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not-so-good Durability for a Fine-Espresso Grinder
reviews.reviewText: We ordered this grinder specifically for grinding whole bean coffee on the espresso machine, using it about once a day in the morning. For some time, the fine grind worked really well on 'medium' setting, producing the right amount of pressure on the espresso machine & resulting in good amount of crema. But after about less than six month, we noticed the ground became less fine to the point where we had to tighten it to the tightest possible setting to ensure the same type of fine grind. We tried brush-cleaning the inside by opening up the grinder assembly to no avail. After about a year, it became clear that even on the finest grind setting (I can't tighten it further) the grind cannot be as fine as before. We noticed the pressure on the espresso machine became lower and lower, and the amount of crema became less and less.

reviews.reviewTitle: Small, non-electric, and gives you a mini-workout
reviews.reviewText: I love this little thing.... I probably wouldn't if I had to use it more than once every couple of days, as it takes quite a while to grind a single espresso's worth, but it's a pretty satisfying task. And I can never remember which direction to turn the grinder to make the grind bigger or smaller... But I am a fan of manually operated products and high quality. I expect this will serve me well for many years, and it's small and portable and attractive. I'm not an expert on grinding quality but it seems to do a good job. Hurray for non-electric appliances!

reviews.reviewTitle: I was so excited to try this to make cold brew coffee as it has really great reviews. The first time I used it the ...
reviews.reviewText:
Do not buy until design of handle changes.
I was so excited to try this to make cold brew coffee as it has really great reviews. The first time I used it the handle would not lock correctly to the top. A simple knob on the top to lock the handle in would have solved this design flaw. This caused it to strip immediately as the metal used is very cheap. While spinning it felt as if the handle was ready to bend or break. Upon further inspection I noticed there was rust on the handle. I was only able to grind 3oz. of coffee before I realized I was wasting my time and this needs to be returned.

I got this grinder before Christmas when I finally decided to start my coffee drinking trail. I wanted to have everything right for the best taste. So I had expectations high when I purchased this model.
It grinds well but the grounds don't have the consistency. I soon noticed the uneven gap around the ceramic center. I didn't wanna return first, but it showed the loose connection between the two main parts. It made a huge mess when the bottom came off when I was grinding one morning last week. That accident helped me make up my mind. I'm turning it.

This came highly reviewed online and on Reddit, and I have been very impressed with its performance in my kitchen. The grind size is very consistent and easy to adjust on the fly, and the grinding itself is as easy as expected for a hand powered unit. While not a problem for me, the volume of beans which can be ground in a single filling is slightly lower than I anticipated (I exclusively brew with a 1.6 L french press, so a full grind or two is fine). Overall, this does an excellent job at getting a consistent grind, and can be easily disassembled for travel or for cleaning/servicing.

Pros:
- Easy to adjust grind size
- Grinds to consistent size
- Easy to clean
- Easy to pack

Cons:
- Small reservoir size for beans and grounds

Having been drinking pre-ground coffee like some kind of savage I decided I needed to up my coffee game. I didnt want to just plow a pile of money into an electric grinder and I appreciated the idea of a manual one to take camping. This one delivered. The adjustable grind lets you dial it in. I use a French press, and the resulting product is leaves me well caffeinated and satisfied that this grinder was the right choice.

The only concern Ive had and I want to stress that it is an extremely minor concern, is that I think the bottom piece where the grinds fall could be just a smidge tighter to the top piece. I expect it will get looser over time from wear, but in reality, were talking hundredths if not thousandths of an inch in diameter and are probably well within manufacturing tolerances without blowing up the price of the device.

Overall, 9.5/10. Would purchase again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Doesn't hol much & Very slow process
reviews.reviewText: I like the construction-seems well made but it really seems designed for travel or espresso, it's way to small and slow for my everyday coffee use. The crank is not affixed and I could see it being lost and the taking apart and putting back together would be confusing, that's why they have an instruction manual for it, it seems. It was also hard for me to hang on to and the 2 parts seemed to be ready to come apart as I cranked. Someone with a much larger hand may not have that problem. The height makes it tippy. All in all it's an expensive mistake for me but may work for others.

Worked great when I first got it. I love the fine control you get over the grind size and how quietly it grinds (I live with a lot of people and no one wants to hear an electric motor whirring away at 5:30 in the morning). The only problem is that the plastic components that keep the burr in place wear away really easily allowing the burr to go off-center really easily, resulting in a super uneven grind.

If you don't mind the uneven grind that you're going to get after a while, then by all means pick this grinder up! Otherwise, I'd say keep looking.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds nicely but a little laborious
reviews.reviewText: This is a good little burr grinder for travel. Especially camping without electric. It grinds nicely fine to course and the window is nice to see your progress. Fine grinding is a little more work and I actually removed the handle and put my small cordless drill/driver on the pin and ran it on low speed to do the grinding for me. Much easier and quicker! Overall a good product but I will probably try to grind a weeks worth of coffee with my heavy duty grinder at home next time just to have a head start on it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not sure how to feel about this one.
reviews.reviewText: It's a compact, stainless steel burr grinder. Its consistent with the grind and relatively cheap. Now for the negative. Its manual so you have a bit of work. Its not the easiest to disassemble and clean but can be done. At first, it was great. Now I am having an issue where the grind setting is changing on its own. I noticed a finer than usual grind. I set it back to coarse. Two days later its back to fine. I was initially impressed with this little grinder and now Im disappointed.

This little coffee grinder is lovely to look at, takes up minimal space, and easy to use and clean. It only takes a couple of minutes to grind just enough beans for my coffee press. I definitely notice the difference in flavor between fresh, hand-ground coffee beans and ones that are ground in a powered machine. What I didn't expect was how satisfying it is to grind the beans by hand. If you care about the flavor of your coffee and you have the time (really just a couple of minutes) to hand grind your beans, then I highly recommend this device.

reviews.reviewTitle: Inconsistent grind; burr seems to be loose & tilted off-center.
reviews.reviewText: After traveling with this a couple of times, the burr seems to have come loose and my grind has gotten even worse than when purchased - which wasn't outstanding to begin with. The plastic insert in the output reservoir makes it more annoying to clean than other manual grinders and doesn't add any value - you should be weighing before you grind, not measuring with the window.

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes great coffee but time consuming
reviews.reviewText:
I have only used the grinder one time to make coffee in my 8 cup Chemex. If you've used a hand grinder before, which I hadn't, you understand how long it took to grind 56 grams of coffee. It was a fun process, and both my 7 and 6 year old enjoyed helping me, but I honestly couldn't imagine taking that long for my 5:00 am coffee. Don't get me wrong, it made great coffee, and at times it could be very useful (I need to be quiet, or I haven't just rolled out of my grave and I want something to do) but for the majority of the time, I'll have to use other means. Next time I'm going to try adding less beans each addition to maybe make the grinding process quicker.

The customer service was very high, which is always a plus and would make me return again for other products.

reviews.reviewTitle: You get what you pay for, average performance, manual effort tiring, cleaning resets setting
reviews.reviewText: For $30 , you know going in you haven't invested too much. Buy it for a trip...take your French press and this grinder and you will get a decent cup of coffee. After guessing the right number of clicks , it does produce a fairly uniform grind. After using twice, I cleaned and removed the ceramic burr grinder to get all the residue out. When putting back together, it isn't easy to know where you last had it set up( which click). So you get a different brew,, when I'm trying to get consistency! After a couple uses as well, the grinding stops and I had to tap beans to get back to grinding, which created different size grinds half way through. And hand grinding does get tiring after the thrill of making your own fresh coffee wears off! It's like the gateway grinder to the really expensive ones! Overall a good but average grinder and I could see myself using at a rental cabin for a weekend trip!

I love this grinder! I used electric ones before this and just couldn't get them right. Now, it's right every time! Getting the setting the way you want it is a little intimidating at first, but just watch Java's on line video and they walk you right through it in easy steps. It's compact enough to take camping and very durable. Would totally recommend it! I've been using it a couple of months so far so haven't had to replace the blade yet, but can say it's holding up nicely.

I've been using a small blade grinder for years (the sound of which always terrifies the dog). I bought some nice coffee beans as a gift for a family member only to find out he didn't have a grinder so I went Amazon shopping. I had heard about the superiority of burr grinders, saw this and they were offering a discount if I purchased two. I really like it, especially being able to dial in the texture of the grind since I alternate between using an Aeropress and a Keurig machine. It also fits in aesthetically on the counter-top in my coffee corner.

This coffee grinder is pretty darn good. I had a problem with the first one shipped, in that the grind preference couldn't be adjusted, but the company's awesome customer service rep (thank you, Jacque!) advised us on trouble shooting. When it was apparent that there was a mechanical problem, they shipped a replacement very quickly and I'm happy to say it works great. I'm in the "senior" age group with some arthritis in my hands, but I can use the coffee grinder easily. A good purchase.

The grinder is good, works well. Grinds consistent. The capacity is smaller than i thought, not fault of anyone buy me not paying close attention to it. The handle for grinding could be easily 4" shorter as it is kind of an odd length for me, if it was shorter i feel i could do more revelations with less effort. Takes quite a bit to get the canister filled up. Like it, use it once and a while for single serve but would not recommend using it for anything bigger.

The Good:
The grinder is very well made. The handle fits snugly, none of the joints are too loose or tight. It's simple and easy to adjust the coarseness of the grind.

The Meh:
It's small, it will only grind enough for two cups of coffee for me using my Aeropress at a time. Which would normally be perfect except for:

The Bad:
It takes FOREVER to grind a small amount of coffee. Going at a constant and fairly rapid spin it takes me 8-10 minutes to fully grind all the beans that the top barrel will hold. I mean, if you want a small shoulder and upper arm workout while you wait to make your coffee at six AM when you need to be making breakfast for 3 kids, packing lunches, getting ready for school and work, cool. If you are that person, you should totally buy this. I don't have an extra HOUR in my week just to set aside for coffee grinding. It will also prob be great for folks with no time constraints who like a little zen in their day.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sweet results(in less than 4 or 8 minutes... exhausting minutes).... But... Better go for a Grinder Machine for instant results.
reviews.reviewText:
This is worth every penny if you are looking to do exercise for 5 minutes, up to 8 minutes if you are grinding for espresso.

Indeed you can grind for an Espresso but keep this in mind "FIND YOUR OWN SETTING" .. Once i grinded to fine, almost extra fine and my espresso machine got stuck.

I've been using it for more than a month, I clean it with a toothbrush afther a week of use.

Update: just stopped grinding afther 3 months of use, turning the handle does nothing now because the plastic rotor broke after exhausting uses( Tilt the machine to grind bean by bean!!)

I make mostly pour over and this grinder does the trick. It is easy to tune the ceramic grinders for different size grind.

I did have one complaint about this product: The knob where the lever attaches eventually wore out. I contacted the company and they answered within 24 hours, completely solving the issue.

There are a lot of grinders on Amazon and they'll all grind your coffee pretty much the same. However, the customer service from JavaPresse is top notch. I'd buy this again just for the quality support.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sturdy, functional, does what it is supposed to do, and EXCELLENT Customer Service!
reviews.reviewText: If you are making coffee for one or two people, this item will provide you with an inexpensive means of grinding coffee beans with ceramic burrs (the recommended hardware) that produce crushed beans, at your preferred grind size, with the potential for excellent flavor extraction (depending on how you brew). It is not as quick as an electric grinder, for sure, but it doesn't cost nearly as much either. It is not lightning quick, but the faster you crank, the faster your beans will be ready. I put my water on to boil and have the beans ground and ready before the water is to temperature. JavaPresse Coffee Company has outstanding customer service! They made contact with me as soon as I placed my order, and assigned me a service rep in the event I had any questions or concerns. I did have one very minor issue, and they resolved that quickly, and well beyond my expectations!

A couple problems with this product:

1. I had difficulty prying the lid off when I first got it --- had to set the lip of the lid on the edge of my counter and pull down quite forcefully.

2. The handle is supposed to slide off and on easily, allowing the lid to be removed. There a pentagon-shaped hole in the handle that slides over a pentagon stub on the grinder. But after using the product for a while with any problems, the handle now gets rotated relative to the stub when grinding, wedging it firmly in place and making it very difficult to remove.

My friend had this coffee grinder and recommended this product for best results. I was pleased with quick shipping confirmation after placing my order and received it within two days with my Amazon Prime membership. The grinder was in simple packaging that had information about the benefits of using a manual coffee grinder. The box also included simple instructions for cleaning and using in addition to a link to a very helpful video of how to make the best cup of brewed coffee. I am very happy with the quality of the grinder and the way it looks. It is very easy to use and does not take more than a couple minutes to get freshly ground coffee beans. With the expensive prices of coffee and lattes that are likely not high quality in stores, this is a much affordable alternative and well worth the investment in this manual coffee grinder. Will definitely be using this daily.

This is exactly what I needed for grinding dry spices and herbs. With the adjustable grind, I can do a uniform coarse pepper or a fine dried thyme. Unlike an electric grinder, I know everything needs to pass through the burr before dropping to the lower chamber. I wouldnt use this for a fresh herb.

reviews.reviewTitle: Solid construction; does what it's intended to do
reviews.reviewText:
I've used this daily for over a week now, and it's great. So you have an idea of this grinder's capacity, I grind 6 tablespoons of beans, and there's still room for maybe 2 more tablespoons.

I should emphasize on thing for people to really consider before buying ANY manual grinder...it will be a workout. If you don't like/want to work out, then I'd recommend an electric grinder.

Overall, it's a great inexpensive alternative to an electric burr grinder as long as you're willing to put in the work. It'd be perfect on my next camping trip, but my buddies will have to grind their own beans.

Let me start here by saying I am NOT a coffee master by any means, but I do enjoy a good cup of coffee. I do mostly pour over, and decided to go with this grinder because of the size and ceramic. From a construction standpoint, its pretty solid. I squeaks a little from normal use but not a big deal. My biggest issue is the grind. Everything people have told me is the key to a good cup is 1. Fresh grind, and 2. Consistent grains size. I attached a photo here so you can take a look, but to me, the grain size is all over the board. Some really small, some course, some medium course. I have done grinds on every setting (fine to corse) and for some reason, they all pop out about the same. On fine, the ratio of fine grounds is more, but there are still large chunks that make their way in. Just a heads up. Maybe my grinder is bad. I have no idea. But just a bit disappointed int he consistency of the grounds.

My initial impression was fantastic, but I soon realized that it takes forever to get a measurable amount of grounds. Perhaps it goes quicker if you're not after a fine grind but for me it was too much. Two shots worth took easily 5-7 minutes of non-stop cranking. That being said, the handle is a bit too long. It allows you to put plenty of torque to the grinder but means you can't go very fast (imagine making big circles with your arm). A shorter handle would still make grinding easy and allow you to go faster and possibly grind everything faster.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wish it included more info in the manual.
reviews.reviewText:
EDIT: AFter 11 months it kicked the bucket. The top cover just lost its shape which results in beans going everywhere when I try to grind. Time to look for a different grinder.

I enjoy using mine. The only thing I wish was that the grind recommendations were in the packaging instead of hidden in their website, ie how many "clicks" are recommended for each setting. They have a manual and other paperwork, not sure why this wasn't included in writing.

That being said, it works as advertised. The grinds aren't 100% consistent but it beats a blade grinder anyday.

reviews.reviewTitle: Small but mighty grinder! Great customer service too.
reviews.reviewText: For a manual coffee grinder, this one is everything you want! Sure, its a bit more work than an automatic, but that just means more love in each cup, right? You get all the flavor benefits of an expensive burr grinder at a fraction of the cost. Not to mention JavaPresse customer service exceeds all expectations. I had an issue with the first one I received (a part came loose the second time I went to clean it). They responded immediately, were very apologetic, and I had a brand new one in my hands two days later! Ive had this one for several weeks now, I use it every day, Ive cleaned it multiple times, and its working great. One day maybe Ill splurge on a fancy automatic burr grinder, but until then Im more than happy to use this sleek, small-but-mighty handheld option. Makes for a great cup of coffee!

reviews.reviewTitle: Good, but vertical crank would be better
reviews.reviewText: This is a pretty good manual coffee grinder, and it yeilds consistent results, but I can see why some other designs use vertically oriented handles. It usually takes me about 90 seconds to crank out enough for a cup which doesn't seem like a lot of time, but it isn't really an ergonomic motion so it can be a pain. On the upside you can hook drill up the top if you don't feel like grinding it manually.

This is a mighty fine coffee grinder, especially for someone who is getting into coffee for the first time and is trying to do it right. The aroma of freshly-ground coffee beans is unbeatable, and if you're making a single cup of coffee for one, this is the grinder you're looking for.

If I had any critiques, I'd like adjusting the setting to be a /bit/ easier and I'd like to see some cleaning instructions included. But all minor things. Grinding is generally effortless, just be sure to be holding both halves of the device's body while you do so. A mighty fine first grinder for a first-time "serious coffee drinker" like me!

This is such a cool item! I'm 80 years old and had no trouble at all figuring out how to use it. I think there was a really helpful video that I watched about using this item. Anyhow, the most important thing for me is ease in turning the handle as my hands are not as strong now as they used to be. I had my coffee beans ground in a very short order with no problems at all. This is a quality item in my opinion and will definitely do the job.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hand grinding coffee can be a great workout.
reviews.reviewText:
I love fresh ground coffee so I bought an electric burr grinder made by a big name company that retails for $50 and it broke within a year. It was too loud, too messy, and too cheaply made so I decided to go in a different direction with my next grinder. I looked online for a ceramic burr hand grinder and found a lot of them. They all looked the same, but I chose the JavaPresse manual coffee grinder. Out of the box, it was easy to use. Instructions were included, but for the most part, were unnecessary. It was easy to see where the beans go and where the grounds end up, but I did need the instructions to adjust the grind for my pour over. The grinder feels solid and the grinder worked well. I gave it four stars for convenience, price, and durability. Here are the reasons why I gave it only 4 stars.
1) The grind adjustment requires knowing a little about how the grind should look. Since I have brewed a lot of coffee in many different ways, I know the difference between a french press grind and a pour over grind. If JavaPresse could tell us how many turns for each grind, it would help beginner coffee geeks.
2) It takes a lot longer to hand grind coffee than you think. I ground 4 Tbs. of coffee for my first pour over and it took almost 5 minutes for a fine grind.
3) I wish the top bolt that the handle attaches to was hexagonal shaped so I could use my cordless drill. I have a small lithium ion drill that would be perfect for powering my grinder, but the top bolt is a pentagon so there isn't a socket that will work. In fact, this is why fire hydrant caps have pentagonal shaped bolts. Unfortunately, this means I cannot use a power drill to save me time and energy. If I could have used my power drill to grind coffee with this grinder, I would give it 5 stars. I will be going to Ace Hardware to see if there is a sleeve I can attach to the pentagonal bolt that will allow me to use my drill.

Other than these three weaknesses, this grinder is exactly as described. It is quiet, it seems durable, it is easy to use, it can be easily disassembled for cleaning if you want to grind things other than coffee, it is inexpensive compared to other grinders that can cost over a thousand dollars, and it arrived quickly.

I like this grinder and feel it is good for the price. I would buy it again. However, be aware that you can only process about 4 scoops of beans at a time so a full pot of coffee will take multiple passes to process. The top and bottom parts slip together and although it is acceptable, they tend to move in your hand while grinding. If they screwed together to hold firmly together while grinding i would have rated 5 stars.

This thing works great for my french press and cold brew! I don't know why others are complaining about how long it takes, unless they're expecting it to be instantaneous or they're grinding all their beans for one week, which is pointless. And you're hand cranking, so what do you expect?! No issues here, I love it and use it everyday! Just be careful when you clean it for the first time, I almost lost the spring down the drain from it unexpectedly jumping out when I opened it up.

This little guy here is well built, and functions exactly as you would think. There is a bit of trial and error getting the grind to the right setting, but it is a manual grinder, so what did you expect? It grinds smoothly with consistent results. Perfect for traveling or not waking up the house in the morning. It takes a minute or two to grind through two tablespoons of whole beans, depending on the grind settings.

**Keep track of all the little parts when you clean it, there are a few washers that want to escape!

Overall, a great little grinder that is easily packable. This and an Aeropress gets you a highly portable high-octane coffee solution!

Okay. So I give it 5 stars because the product works perfectly, great for individual cups of coffee and is small and portable. HOWEVER, you get tired of grinding your own beans real fast. Especially if you are trying to make more than one cup of coffee. Great little machine, but after about 2 weeks you realize the need for an electric grinder. Also, I was taking it apart to clean and you have to be very careful. Inside there's a lot of little bolts and springs. When I loosed one thing, it shot off and I lost a piece down the sink. It still works, but I'm just glad I didn't loose something more important (I think it was a mini-washer??). Overall, great buy if you are starting out and don't know if you really need your own grinder. Some people might have no problem with hand cranking for 5 minutes. It's really up to the person, but as for me and my fiance, it was a great first buy, but we are definitely going to upgrade soon.
This worked great ...for a month. Completely fell apart after 30 day return window was up.

I've been grinding coffee with this grinder for most of this year already. I've ground about 7 pounds of various blends for various brews and have cleaned the grinder, by hand, after each change of blend. On Friday, after finishing my last blend of beans, I took the grinder apart to clean and discovered the plastic washer that sits atop the spring along the crank rod had broken in half and one half of it was missing. I wonder which cup I drank the washer!!

I sent a note to Javapresse telling my story and requested a replacement washer. Daphne responded to my request on Saturday and after providing her my order number, she notified me a set of washers and spring were being sent to me free of charge. I received the package on Tuesday and ground my first cup of French Press today and am back in business of enjoying fresh ground coffee at home. Thanks to Daphne for such attentive and cordial response to get me back to the grind in fast order.

Works as advertised, easy to use, time will tell if it's durable or not. I dinged two stars because of the design. I'm an engineer and inefficient lever design bugs me! Rotating the handle on the top (parallel to ground) is just not natural and starts hurting my arms; not to mention I keep bumping my fingers on the metal edge. I don't understand why couldn't make it up/down rotating system, like pedaling a bicycle.

Nice manual coffee grinder. It gives a fairly even grind on the coarse settings (I use a percolator, so the coarser the better) The ceramic burrs seem nice enough, and the lower one could be replaced if parts were offered.

The lid occasionally falls off and the handle regularly falls off though. The problem is that the handle needs to be easily removable to add more coffee, so any positive attachment would interfere with that. A spring loaded design similar to what's on the burr side of the shaft could be made to work, but it would eventually fail and would definitely make the grinder more expensive. The shaft is also a pentagon rather than the normal hexagon, so a standard wrench or nut driver can't be used (not that that would be a good idea anyway). If you lose the handle, you don't have many options for a replacement.

Very happy with this grinder. Takes me about 4 mins to grind the beans for an entire 12 cup coffee maker. It goes quickly and the smell of fresh ground beans is wonderful. Cleaning this is very easy. I decided to use a new toothbrush to clean the ceramic parts. I find it is better than a Q- tip. I air dry the pieces overnight. Very easy to put back together. I like that this is compact in size. Great product and fast shipping.

reviews.reviewTitle: I Love and hate this grinder (keep reading)
reviews.reviewText:
This is a real verified review- no favors here.
Gosh I love this grinder,. I found the perfect setting and I just appreciate the quality of great tasting coffee I get using this , with quality beans and espresso maker.
Its just that I wish I can press a button and be over with it. Right? I mean I need to get to work. That said, it takes a bit longer but even my kids like to do it on weekends. Just a satisfying task, but takes a bit longer than a machine. I don't hate it really. I love it.

It takes me about 2 minutes to grind enough beans for 6 six ounce cups of coffee. I think the coffee tastes better than it did when I used my electric grinder. I have used the gadget about a month and it has worked flawlessly. I don't know how long it will last, but I know the battery will not need replacing and the motor will keep going as long as my arm muscles keep working. I have no idea why I am supposed to evaluate the unit's versatility. It grinds my coffee, period.

reviews.reviewTitle: does a great job grinding coffee
reviews.reviewText: I use this grinder in our RV to make my morning coffee. My coffee brand says always to grind beans fresh or they lose 50% of their flavor! I'm not having that! So I bought this hand grinder. It does a great job and the grind is easily adjustable, from finest to coarse. I get my morning exercise turning the (extra long) handle! It does a really great job of grinding beans and I know my coffee is always fresh and tasty. The grinder looks pretty elegant, too! Stainless steel, it will never rust. Love it!

I will start off by saying I am not a coffee expert by any means. I am a beginner as far as coffee goes outside of a traditional coffee pot. I read like reviews on this item and though it would be at least worth trying for the money.
When I received the grinder it was very well packaged and was not damaged at all. In the box was a thank you not as well as a link to some great videos on how to get started.
The company also sent me an email on how to get started and what to do when you first get it, which was extremely helpful considering I had never used one before. Once you put a few beans through to make sure there are no little bits of stuff in it, you're ready to go!
You couldn't ask for a better manual coffee grinder. It is very easy to crank, the set up is very simple, and the grind is consistent. The burr is very easy to adjust, so you can go from super fine espresso coffee to super coarse French press style coffee. There isn't much noise at all that comes from it, which is quite pleasant when I have two kids I try to not wake up on the weekends while making coffee.
The capacity isn't substantial but it is great for just a couple cups worth in a French press, which is my choice of brewing method. The grinder fits in my hand nicely, so it doesn't make it awkward trying to grind the beans.
Overall I am very pleased with this coffee grinder. It is very affordable, quiet, consistent, and doesn't require anything but your choice of beans. I would recommend this item to anyone looking for something simple and easy!

The grinder is O.K., the stop for the adjustment doesn't seem to be very strong, it's hard to find where to start counting clicks. It takes a whole lot of grinding to get three tablespoons of beans ground, and some larger pieces don't get ground without shaking/tilting the grinder.

If I'm going to stick with "pour over" coffee making I'll look for one that works better.

For an inexpensive grinder for infrequent use and a good workout, it's O.K.

I had a Hero grinder until the burr wore down, but I found it cumbersome and uncomfortable to hold while grinding. This JavaPresse is much easier. It's a compact size and you can move the handle and the base in opposite directions while grinding, which makes the whole job easier. Since the handle can be stored separately, it doesn't take up much space. I like the fact that you can order replacement burrs, too. All in all, very pleased.

reviews.reviewTitle: Take the grinder, leave the baloney....
reviews.reviewText: Very smooth operation, decent adjustability, well made item. I bought for use in my travel/camping kit - not for every day usage. I don't suggest accepting any invitations from JavaPresse to sign up for added information. I now seem to have a new email pen-pal who sends daily suggestions for how this grinder and their coffee club will change my life! Didn't buy it from EST in the 70s, nor now... Still, it is a great grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works pretty similar to my Haro grinder.
reviews.reviewText:
Works pretty similar to my Haro grinder. I was on the fence for quite awhile looking for a second grinder, one for work, one for home. There are so many companies that make such a similar product, it's hard to figure out why one costs more than the other. I would put this product about on par with my Haro. The Haro has an indicator on the side of the grounds container, so you know when you've got enough for 1 or 2 cups. But after you use your grinder for awhile, you kind of figure out the right amount of beans without needing the indicator.

I do find this grinder a little easier than the Haro when holding it in the air. In other words, the Haro seems to work more efficient when I hold it steady on the counter. Don't ask me why exactly.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is MORE than just a manual coffee grinder.
reviews.reviewText: This manual coffee grinder is really great. I like it so much better than my electric grinder. There is more control over the grind and it just becomes a natural process that I look forward to every morning when I get up. Typicallly, I need coffee before can function well, but waiting until this is ground to the specifications I have chosen, has worked out very well for me. Actually, while grinding, there is a bit of time for reflection. This time helps me to set my mood and attitude for the day instead of going as fast as i can to get that coffee started and running around just as fast to get things started for the day.

Ive used this coffee grinder for a few weeks now, and I can tell you this one works. If youre just grinding up one cups worth, and enjoy the intimacy between you and the beans, it serves ya well!
Works great for pour over coffee. I would recommend this manual coffee bean grinder to anyone. Compact and very handy, very simple to use and disassemble.

Thank you!! Excellent customer service on top of all that :)
Unrealistic, takes 10+ minutes to grind enough beans to use to make coffee

reviews.reviewTitle: Once I had a real Javapresse things were better.
reviews.reviewText:
This product worked fine for a little over two months, then the handle broke. I consulted the literature in the packaging and it had instructions to contact Javapresse directly about product malfunctions. Imagine my surprise when, after several great exchanges, Javapresse let me know that I had purchased a fake product from an unauthorized reseller, and that they were already taking legal action with Amazon about it.

So I have a broken coffee grinder after only two months of usage, and the Amazon return window is closed. I feel screwed.

**Update**
I contacted Amazon and they issued a partial refund when I returned the defective product.

I then went out and purchased an actual Javapresse grinder and wow. What a difference. Some of the things that had seemed like bad design about my fake product were magically solved. It can now stand upright with the handle on it. I love it, Im happy, and if youre interested in manually grinding your coffee this is an excellent product. Just be sure you buy an authentic product from the right retailer.
